DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HON. SIR PERCY SPENDER, KCVO, KBE, QC

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death of the Hon. Sir Percy Claude Spender, KCVO, KBE, QC, a former Minister and member for the division of Warringah, who died on Friday, 3 May 1985, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his wife and family.

Sir Percy Spender was born above his father's locksmith shop in Darlinghurst in 1897 and spent his boyhood in Sydney. His academic career, as a young man, was distinguished by a university medal and first class honours in law at Sydney University. After only 11 years at the Bar after his graduation he became a King's Counsel, at the age of 37. He was elected to Parliament in 1937, reputedly as the result of a challenge to put his vigorous views to the test. He was elected for the seat of Warringah and served in this chamber for 14 years. He rose quickly to the Ministry and served in the War Cabinet in the dark years from 1939 to 1941. He was at different times Treasurer, Minister for the Army and Minister for External Affairs and External Territories.

It was perhaps in this last portfolio that Sir Percy made his greatest contribution to Australian public life. As Australia's Foreign Minister, he appreciated the importance to Australia of Asia and the Pacific region and he understood the fundamental necessity of the Australian-American alliance. Through his belief in and commitment to this alliance he played a central role in the conclusion of the ANZUS Treaty. History has honoured this commitment. ANZUS became and has remained the cornerstone of Australia's defence arrangements. It has served Australia well for over 30 years now and continues to serve it well.

Sir Percy's service to his country did not end with his retirement from this House in 1951. In that year he was appointed Australia's Ambassador to the United States of America where he continued for seven years to build on the ties formally established under the ANZUS Treaty. In 1958 he was appointed to the International Court of Justice at The Hague and in 1964 he was elected as its President. Within the Court he was regarded with the highest respect. Even in retirement, Sir Percy continued to contribute to public and political life in this country.

Sir Percy Spender's life was marked by achievement at the Bar, against many of the sharpest minds of his time, in this Parliament, where he met the challenges of domestic and foreign policy, and on the world stage in the International Court of Justice. It was a life dedicated to the service of his country and one without which Australians would be demonstrably poorer. Madam Acting Speaker, on behalf of the Government I extend to his widow and to his family, including his son John, who carries on the family tradition in this House, our sincerest sympathy and our regret at the passing of a distinguished Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). This is, in many ways, a rare and difficult occasion when we pay tribute to a great Australian whose son is with us in the Parliament today. We know of the achievements of the father of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender)-some of us knew his father-but, for all we may say, the honourable member, who knew his father only too well, will think of him as a loving son would think of a father whose death he is mourning.

SPEECH.PARA: I warmly support what the Prime Minister said for the late Sir Percy Spender certainly fits into the category of an extraordinarily distinguished Australian. He was a jurist, a parliamentarian and a diplomat of the highest standing. His achievements were not only notable but also enduring. It falls to very few to be able to play a role in this Parliament and to even fewer to be able to forge for their nation policies that endure for decades. The Prime Minister correctly referred to the central role that Sir Percy forged in the ANZUS alliance, and endorsed that alliance today. Sir Percy also played an extraordinarily significant role in the formation of the Colombo Plan which, with his advocacy being so strong, was known for a short time as the Spender Plan.

Today we have a number of principal elements in our foreign policy. Two elements are the alliance with the United States of America and our relationship with Asia. Both of these elements were forged by Sir Percy, and they endure today. If we could steer through some legislation that lasted for the term of a parliament, we would think it a significant contribution. These two elements of our foreign policy have endured through three and a half decades, beyond the life of the man who forged them, and that in itself is an extraordinarily high tribute to the work and the ability of Sir Percy.

The Prime Minister correctly referred to Sir Percy's humble background. I recall him on one occasion cheerfully admitting to me that in his school days he was no outstanding scholar; yet he went on, as was recounted by the Prime Minister, from being a boy who at first had failed to matriculate to finally graduating with first class honours and the University Medal for Law.

Sir Percy entered this Parliament in 1937, making his mark in the portfolios that the Prime Minister mentioned. He served as Treasurer and as Minister for the Army before the Second World War, playing a major role in the creation of the Second Australian Imperial Force, having been a member of the First AIF. In opposition, he served for a time on the Advisory War Council and, on the return of the Menzies Government in 1949, he brought his knowledge of international affairs and the law to bear in creating a new stature and a new influence for Australia in the conduct of its international policies.

There is no doubt that Sir Percy Spender was a man of diverse interests, with the service of his life to the community in the international and domestic scenes and the writing of major books on law and politics. We mourn the passing of a very great Australian. I have spoken personally to John Spender and my Party feels as deeply as I do that the nation has lost a great Australian. We appreciate his courage in being with us in the House today during this extremely difficult time for him and his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are few who have contributed more over the course of 84 years since Federation to the development and growth of this nation of ours than the late Sir Percy Spender. He was a great Australian. The motion of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), properly identifies the character, history and traditions of the man whom today we mourn. There is no doubt that his association, within this Parliament and without, in the service of this nation brought a unique distinction to Australia. He was a prominent barrister, a Federal Minister in several portfolios, Vice-President of the General Assembly of the United Nations, Ambassador to Washington and President of the International Court of Justice. There are few in our time who have achieved greater distinction or who have worn it so ably and so well.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us do well to remember, as my colleague the Leader of the Opposition has just remarked, that he contributed in legislative form and in diplomatic endeavour to a number of developments that still are very significant for this nation. His association with the ANZUS Treaty is perhaps the most notable, yet we all need to remember that the Colombo Plan, which rendered such tremendous service in developing relations between Australia and other countries around the world, was originally called the Spender Plan. It certainly played a tremendously significant part in the development and association of Australia and the countries of South East Asia. His achievements in law, politics and diplomacy are very much a memorial to the man, the father and, above all, the Australian.

A great deal was said in the course of the remarks of the last two speakers about the way in which, from his humble origins, he achieved academic distinction and then public recognition. But we need to remember that it was at an important time in Australia's history that we had a man of his ability to perform in the way he did. It is interesting to recall that he joined the War Cabinet, becoming Treasurer and then Minister for the Army in 1940. Following the election of the Chifley Government, he became a member of the Advisory War Council. It is interesting also, to put history into perspective, to recall that he was expelled from the United Australia Party in 1944 when he decided to remain on the Council after the departure of his UAP colleagues. Of course, he was later invited to join the then newly created Liberal Party and he became Minister for External Affairs and External Territories when the Liberal-Country Party Government came to office in 1949.

This was the period in which the foundation of modern Australia was laid. Sir Percy played a prominent part in that work. Sir Percy is perhaps best remembered for his role in the birth of the ANZUS Treaty. When he became Minister for External Affairs he threw himself into the task of securing the United States-Australian pact in the Pacific. He forged personally a close relationship with President Truman and the then Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. Those efforts were crowned in 1951 when Sir Percy represented Australia at the signing of the ANZUS Treaty in San Francisco. Of course, it was shortly after that that he left political life and became Ambassador to Washington. It was in that capacity that he attended the inaugural ANZUS Conference in Honolulu in 1952. He helped see the ANZUS Conference through its infancy and in his seven years as Ambassador to Washington saw it reach a strong and admired maturity. This was a very important achievement for which alone he would be remembered with respect by this House and by all Australians.

However, even after Sir Percy stepped down as Ambassador, his public life was to continue. He was knighted in 1952 and, in 1958, he was appointed to the International Court of Justice in The Hague. In 1964, he was appointed to a three-year term as President of that Court. In 1966, he led the Australian delegation to the second Suez conference; and, in 1967, he retired from the Bench. In almost 20 years of retirement, which ended with his death on 3 May at the age of 87, Sir Percy remained active. He wrote books on politics, diplomacy and the law. He had an extensive speaking program and, amongst other activities, he chaired a board to form a national index of Australian birds.

Sir Percy was well known to many on both sides of the House. His influence on successive Australian governments and on the individuals who were part of those governments was profound. On behalf of the National Party, I extend to John, the honourable member for North Sydney, to his brother Peter, to their families and to Sir Percy's widow, the deepest personal sympathy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to join in supporting the motion of condolence to the family of the late Sir Percy Spender, who was one of the most significant Australians to have been a member of this Parliament. I do so in the context of his being a distinguished member of the legal profession and also a very worthy representative of Australia in foreign policy. In foreign affairs and defence, he foresaw threats and dangers that nobody else did at that time. He was the first to alert Australians to the fact that they were virtually on their own should any aggression take place in the Pacific-which it did. He foreshadowed that aggression.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming from a very poor beginning, Sir Percy was a man who had no special advantages but achieved eminence in the fields of politics, law and international statesmanship. Obviously, he will long be remembered, as has already been said, because of his efforts in respect of the Colombo Plan and the ANZUS Treaty, but also for his efforts on behalf of Australia in times of war.

It is said with some humour that he never really supported Labor, and that he admitted that he was elected to Parliament on Australian Labor Party preferences. He endeared himself to Labor members of Parliament because they were very mindful of his nationalism. He was a great colleague and friend of the late Dr Evatt, because they were at Fort Street High School at the same time and had much in common. Also, he was a great friend and colleague of the late John Curtin of famous memory, and Sir Percy supported Curtin in his most anxious moments of ensuring that Australia might survive in that period of World War II.

Apart from those particular matters, however, Sir Percy had a broader vision that would bring Australia to the achievement of its identity as a nation. Not only was he the President of the International Court of Justice, in which he performed outstanding work on an international basis, but, subsequent to his retirement, he continued to take a keen interest in international affairs. He delivered an historic paper on the Great Barrier Reef and its legal aspects at the Australian Conservation Foundation Symposium on 3 May 1969. The submissions made in that paper by Sir Percy were subsequently approved in toto by the High Court of Australia in what is called the seas and submerged lands case, decided in 1973, in which the High Court recognised and declared that sovereignty and sovereign rights in the off-shore areas lie with the national government.

Sir Percy was a man much before his time, who was much loved by those who opposed him but who respected his humanity and skill. I place on record my support for the motion which expresses condolences to his widow and to his family-particularly to John, who is with us today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to concur with the motion and the remarks placed on record by the other speakers. Apart from his being so greatly respected in international legal circles and in the United States of America, Sir Percy is still remembered most fondly in Sri Lanka. This point was made to me by the President of Sri Lanka when I went to his home some years ago as a Minister of the previous Government. The first thing we did was to go down the hallway to his sitting room to see on the wall a photograph of those Ministers who signed the Colombo Plan. The President, who was a Minister in the Sri Lankan Government at that time, pointed to Sir Percy's photograph with affection as well as great respect. I found in my subsequent consultations with younger members of the current Sri Lankan Government that one of the reasons for their strong feelings of affinity with Australia was Sir Percy and the Colombo Plan. There are a number of stories of Sir Percy, some of which are perhaps apocryphal now, which have done Australia a power of good, in addition to the actions which the speakers before me have mentioned which show him to have been an extraordinarily distinguished representative of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my support to this condolence motion. Naturally, like everybody else in this House, I did not serve with Sir Percy. I had the pleasure of meeting him on only a couple of occasions. When I did I drew his attention to a speech that he made in this House in 1938 which I think was an outstanding one. Honourable members will recall that, in 1938, the Jewish people were going through one of the most difficult periods in their history. At that time a conference was called at Avion in France to decide what would be done about the Jews of Europe, and in particular of Germany. Australia was represented at that conference and decided to take 7,000 Jews as refugees.

SPEECH.PARA: When the motion to do that was debated in this House a particularly virulent anti-Semitic speech was made by the then member for Kalgoorlie, regrettably a member of my Party. That in itself is not unusual. It reflected, in a sense, the attitudes of the time. It was quite common for people to be anti-Semitic. What was appalling was that only two members of this House took the opportunity to dissociate themselves from the speech. One was the then member for Melbourne, Dr Maloney, and the other was Sir Percy Spender. He made what I considered to be an outstanding contribution in condemning the speech that had been made and in showing understanding and compassion for the problems of the Jewish people. For that reason I have always had a very soft spot for him. I took the opportunity of congratulating him on what I thought was an outstanding contribution. The Jewish people can be grateful that, at that time, one of the few friends they had was in this House. I take this opportunity to add my sympathy and to pay my respects to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The people of Warringah remember Sir Percy Spender with a great deal of affection. As we have already heard, he was the member for Warringah from 1937 to 1951. He won that seat as an independent. There are still stories of the campaign that was waged in 1937. He was up against Sir Archdale Parkhill, who was a Minister at the time. Sir Percy, as characterised his entire life, was absolutely indefatigable in his campaigning. The chief method of campaigning that he used to great effect in those days was the barbecue. The electorate of Warringah in those days stretched from Mosman to Palm Beach and barbecues were held frequently all along the peninsula. Sir Percy enjoyed a party. He enjoyed the barbecues and he made a great impression on those who attended them. He also made a special of street corner meetings, and the ones he held opposite the hotel at Spit Junction are still spoken about to these days. There is another story about Sir Percy's success in that election which relates not so much to his strength and ability but to the fact that Sir Archdale Parkhill wore spats to the surf lifesaving carnivals of the day and thereby lost a very great number of votes.

SPEECH.PARA: During Sir Percy's time as member for Warringah he was assisted very greatly by his wife. He is remembered, as I have said, as a man with the common touch, who mixed very well with the people-a busy, practical man, but a man with a light touch, a man with a considerable range of talents as a public figure. We have heard some of the details of those. At the national level he undoubtedly was a man of very effective decisiveness. I think it is absolutely true to say that he was one of Australia's great Foreign Ministers. He had a large, intellectual capacity and exceptional political insights. That is nowhere better demonstrated than in the speed with which he moved to commit Australian support to defend South Korea. We know that historically this was a major factor in the stabilisation of the Pacific at a time when Japan was beginning to come to terms with the new relationship with the West. Failure to act decisively in Korea would have exposed Japan to a very uncertain future. As I have already said, Sir Percy was a man of great decisiveness.

It was his insight which demonstrated the simple truth that an independent foreign policy is the capacity to make independent judgments about the issues of the day. Nobody could say that he ever acted other than from the inner resources of his intellect and his political acumen. He did so with Australia's interests firmly in mind at all times. I think that it is fitting that his is the Australian signature on the ANZUS Treaty.

Throughout his term as Ambassador to the United States of America, he brought to his task a vigorous independence of mind and he represented Australian perspectives with considerable dignity and distinction. He had a lively sense of humour, which is reflected in his memoirs, Politics and A Man. In it he quotes another leading politician of the time, Arthur Fadden. After Fadden's short term as Prime Minister came to an end, he said to Sir Percy, as they were walking along the Sydney railway terminal, something with which I think we all would concur. Fadden said: 'You learn as you go along, Percy. When you're out, you're bloody well out'.

Sir Percy demonstrated all his life a capacity of great intellectual vigour. Bringing to bear his attention to the problems of the day never stood in his way of acceptance of the lighter side of life which meant so much to him.

His life was long and well lived and an extremely valuable one for Australia. His passing leaves us with a sense of sadness. We are privileged to have with us as a member of this House the honourable member for North Sydney, his son, John. I, and all the residents of Warringah, join with this House in expressing to John, his family and all of Sir Percy's family a very great sadness at his father's passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to thank those who have spoken and perhaps trespass for a few minutes on the House's time to say something of the man because much is known of what he has done but perhaps not as much is known of the man himself. The loss of a great man is not simply an occasion for sadness, although grief is inseparable from the event; it is a time for public remembrance and thanks and for rejoicing in a life which has been richly spent.

SPEECH.PARA: Something has been said of his early life. It was not an easy one; he did not come from privileged circumstances and he never forgot that fact. He was born on 5 October 1897. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said, he was the son of a locksmith. His mother died when he was five, and the years after that were not easy ones. He was a sickly child and a shy child and he had a fearful stutter. That is astonishing when one thinks of the things which he went on to achieve. He was living away from home at the age of 16. He was a student at Fort Street High School and, in a marvellous final class of 1914, 40 of the 42 students matriculated and qualified for entrance to Sydney University. My father was one who failed. He failed Latin. He detested the subject. He thought it was a dead language and there was no need to revive it. So he had to go and find himself a job.

He went to work at the Town Hall as a clerk. His old headmaster, a most remarkable man, Dr Kilgour, who must have seen something extraordinary in him, came and sought him out. At this time my father wanted to play football for Australia; that was his abiding passion. I think he also wanted to become an actor. God alone knows what would have happened or where I would be had that taken place. His headmaster came to him and said: 'Spender, give up your ideas of football renown. I have seen more than one young chap who wore the Australian cap, and they all finished up with the backsides out of their pants'. So he coached my father in Latin. He passed, took the State's Public Board examinations, topped those examinations and went to Sydney University as a night student in arts and law, working by day. He moved from the Town Hall to be a clerk of petty sessions at the Newtown court. He told me that his first job there was to issue dog licences, which I am sure he did with great efficiency.

He was gifted with great determination of purpose, a most penetrating intellect, immense powers of concentration and a prodigious capability for work. We have heard something of his university career. Working by day and studying by night, he won a number of prizes as he went through university. As the Prime Minister has said, he won the University Medal and took first class honours. I believe he was the only part time student who had achieved that distinction. It was said to him that he could be a Rhodes Scholar if he wanted to, but he was a poor man and lacked the means; so he had to say no.

He entered law without any close connections in the legal fraternity, as some people have, and was offered a very lucrative partnership with a firm of attorneys. He was not then married to my mother. He wished to marry her but he needed money and of course had he entered the partnership he could have married her more quickly. She was a person of iron will-indeed, I think her will matched his. She advised him not to enter the partnership. He paid great heed to her judgment and so he went to the Bar-without patrons, with nothing but the intellect and drive which fortune had given him and which he had nourished. He started off in a small room, he told me, with one chair for the client, one chair for himself, a desk, a few books bought on time payment and one bookcase. He never looked back. He became a King's Counsel at the age of 37, and I believe that he was then the youngest King's Counsel in the British Commonwealth.

But politics was something which was tugging at him; the confines of the law were too narrow. He became deeply interested in national affairs and was trenchantly critical of the coalition government of the time and of Sir Archdale Parkhill, who was the Defence Minister. He entered politics in a way which was characteristic of him. He believed that we could not rely upon Great Britain in the event of a major war in Europe; he believed that we should direct our attention primarily to air defence, to a mechanised and mobile army, to fast and small surface vessels and to submarines. One evening in 1937 at Bowral, after dinner, a number of people were sitting around talking and he was expressing his views in his usual way, which was, I would say, with great confidence and with a fair amount of assertiveness. A friend of Parkhill's said to my father: 'You have had a hell of a lot to say, Spender, on a subject you cannot know very much about. If you really believe all that you have been saying why don't you stand against Parkhill and tell the public what you think, and see where you finish?'

My father was constitutionally incapable of resisting a challenge. He took up that challenge, and had my mother as his campaign director. As the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) has said, it was very much a barbecue and street corner kind of campaign-working by day, campaigning by night. As the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) pointed out, he won, and he won on Australian Labor Party preferences. I hope it will not be taken as a partisan comment if I say that that does demonstrate that Labor voters cannot always be wrong. As honourable members might imagine, his reception here by the former colleagues of Archdale Parkhill was somewhat frosty. After a year he joined the United Australia Party, and his career in politics was such that one of his adversaries nick-named him 'Out Again, In Again, Back Again Spender'.

His public achievements have been touched upon and I will not seek to isolate them. Perhaps I could have time to touch on four or five. He laid the groundwork for the financial planning for the war. I quote one very brief passage from the official history which refers to a memorandum that he prepared in February 1940:

The memorandum from the Acting Treasurer showed the clearest appreciation of what a wartime economy involved, a clarity which was undoubtedly due to Spender's willingness, already noted in connection with the November budget, to seek advice and views from the Financial and Economic Committee, and his readiness to discuss with its chairman rather than to accept the traditional approach of Treasury officials.

That is something which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) may have a certain sympathy for. I think he laid down much of the basis for the administration of the Army. He appointed a civilian business manager to look after such matters as the ordering and delivery of the Army's supplies and the relations of the Army with other departments. Incidentally, he came to the view that the first thing the Department sought to do to a new Minister was to snow him with paper work. When he first arrived at Victoria Barracks he was given a pile of papers which he was told he had to sign. He asked why and he was told that the regulations said so. He said: 'Very well, I will sign them, but the regulations have to be changed'. They had to be changed so he would be freed from the consideration of routine matters and no documents were to come before him that did not involve a question of policy or a matter of important military or political significance-a general guide to all Ministers. He records in his memoirs the following comment:
The thought crossed my mind, that the time of the Minister was to be occupied in this way--
that is, by signing documents-
so that he would have the less time to interfere with the experts.
His work on the Colombo Plan and on the ANZUS Treaty has been touched on, as has his work at the International Court of Justice.

If I could trespass a little longer and say something about the private man. He was a profoundly and determinedly independent man. He was a committed nationalist. He never knew what it was to be anything but Australian. He could never understand people who did not understand what it was to be an Australian. He could never subordinate his political interests to fundamental national interests, and that was illustrated by his expulsion from the UAP. The decision was made in February 1944 by the UAP to withdraw from the Advisory War Council. Mr Menzies, Mr Hughes and my father were members of that Council. My father refused and he made a public statement at the time. He said this:

We are as yet a long way from victory, and much must be endured, and many thousands of lives sacrificed before we reach the end of the road. My first and over-riding obligation is to the nation. This approach, and this approach alone, particularly in time of war, must condition one's conduct.

Menzies warned him that this might be the end of his political career. He was expelled and one of the headlines was 'Exit Spender', from politics, rather like the headline that greeted Truman in 1948 when it was said that Dewey had been elected President. Perhaps it was this occasion that prompted him to give me some advice about life in general and politics in particular, if I should ever enter politics. It was this: 'Never resign, John, let the bastards throw you out'.

He was, Madam Acting Speaker, a formidable and unyielding political opponent, an outstanding debater with a pungent, biting and wounding tongue, yet he did not engage in personalities. He had the closest of relations, which has been pointed out, with, amongst others, John Curtin, whom he thought to be the outstanding wartime Prime Minister-of both world wars. He was by nature a generous and kind man. He never lost his capacity for moral outrage. I can recall one occasion when he was President of the Court when he came back from overseas. He always opened his mail and read it. There was a letter from an old constituent who still thought that Spender was her member. She was a pensioner and I think she had problems concerning eviction. She wanted advice. He did what was characteristic of him: He sat down and immediately wrote to her giving her such advice as he could as to what she could do. I do not think there are many people so placed who would have taken the trouble to do that.

My father had a great zest for life, an absence of pomposity and a contempt for those who, having achieved some position in life, drew about them the non-existent cloak of greatness. He never forgot a friend and I think he had a fairly good memory for his enemies. I do not suggest for a moment that he was a man without faults; he was not. He had a deep contempt for those who pursued wealth, or power without principle, or who were content to let other Australians bear the burden of war. He was a very brave man. I can recall when he was 50 or more years of age he carried out a most dangerous surf lifesaving operation at Palm Beach, risking his life to save that of a friend.
He was a most loving father.

I have attempted to sum up his views. Far be it from me to try to claim objectivity. He could be the most difficult and pugnacious of men, exacting on himself and demanding on others. His faults were large but so were his virtues. He was in all ways a big man and, I think, a great Australian. Two stories about him best epitomise the man he was, stories which he always repeated to me and which he never forgot. When he was a young barrister he attended the farewell of a judge of the Supreme Court of New South Wales. The judge said:
I have tried to do my duty; no man can do more; no man should do less.

Another occasion was very early in his life, when he was a night student at the University of Sydney and was taught philosophy by Professor Francis Anderson, a man who had a very great influence on him. He recalled the story, which he repeated to me and which he has repeated in his memoirs, about how, in the night time, as the lecture was about to end, a shaft of moonlight came through the window and struck the desk at which Professor Anderson was standing. The professor held up his hands and said: 'With the soul within and the heavens above, nothing is impossible'. So it is with each one of us. So it is with our country. I thank the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been informed of the absence of the Speaker because of his unfortunate illness. I am sure that all honourable members will join with me in wishing the Speaker a swift and complete recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Speaker, I endorse the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and trust that you will convey to the Speaker the wishes of all honourable members.
—I thank the House. I will do so.

—I refer the Prime Minister to his commitment of 22 April to announce in May expenditure savings decisions of at least $1 billion. Will the Prime Minister assure the House that this $1 billion does not incorporate expenditure savings decisions already announced; for instance, increased charges for overseas students, road grants to the States and local government and superannuation contributions to public servants in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made clear when I made the announcement the reality of the expenditure cuts that would be announced on 14 May. I simply content myself with saying that, if the Leader of the Opposition will contain his impatience, he will find out on the night of 14 May-Tuesday of next week-when the Treasurer makes his statement that there will be cuts in real terms of at least $1 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: I have had cause to say before, and I repeat now, that we on this side of the House, particularly those of us who have had the onerous responsibility of operating in the Expenditure Review Committee, have been more than amused by the inferences of those on the other side of the House that some cosmetic exercise will be engaged in. I therefore expect them, after the evening of 14 May, to assure those around the country who will be complaining about the decision that they have no cause for concern; that it has been merely a cosmetic exercise in which the Government has been engaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Treasurer indicate whether a Press report this morning that $4 billion of tax is being evaded, because the corporate sector is not reporting all its taxable income, is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to a story in today's Australian Financial Review, which claims to report the contents of a confidential Australian Taxation Office document about tax evasion. Unfortunately, this story is both highly sensationalised and seriously inaccurate. It is true that the report to which the Financial Review refers has not been publicly released. Nevertheless, it is an interim report of a group which came into existence by virtue of a decision by the Commissioner of Taxation. The existence of the group was announced in the last annual report of the Tax Commissioner, so there is nothing particularly secret about the report.

ANSWER.PARA: The most important element in today's report in the Financial Review is that it seriously misquotes the figures contained in the report. It states that the corporate sector is evading tax of between $3 billion and $4 billion each year. The report does not contain any estimate of losses in respect of the corporate sector. In fact, the report dealt with unincorporated enterprises income of the order of $3 billion to $4 billion and tax equivalent losses of the order of $1 billion on income of $3 billion to $4 billion. So, it is not $3 billion to $4 billion of company tax which is missing; in fact, we are looking at the prospect of losses of the order of $1 billion for unincorporated enterprises.

As well as that, there was an inference made in the report that no adjustments were made other than that the assessors were able to yield about $21.6m per annum in assessing unincorporated enterprises. This is also incorrect. As mentioned in the Commissioner's sixty-third annual report, the Australian Taxation Office enforcement programs in 1983-84 were responsible for adjustments, following audit and investigation action, of some $510m, $201m of which relates to non-corporate tax payers. In other words, the report is sensationalised and highly inaccurate. It has been recognised as a fact in this Parliament for a long time that there is straight evasion and underreporting of income. This is a fact across the spectrum, but particularly in the area of unincorporated enterprises.

One of the causes of the fact that compliance with our taxation system has broken down is the disrepute in which the tax system is held and was held through the 1970s when tax avoidance was permitted on a massive scale by the Government of the day. Underreporting of income has, indeed, become part of a very unsavoury fashion. Up until the early 1970s we had a high degree of compliance with the tax system and I am sad to say that that is not the case today. But losses in respect of the unincorporated area of taxation are of the order of $1 billion through straight evasion and underreporting. That is totally different from the $3 billion to $4 billion being described as 'loss of taxation to the corporate sector'. This report was about unincorporated enterprises and the figure was of the order of $1 billion, not $3 billion to $4 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Does he still adhere to the promise he made before the last election that interest rates would fall in 1985?

—I would have thought that just about the last thing in the world that the honourable member for Bennelong would want to talk about would be interest rates. I do not believe that in the volatile circumstances that have occurred in Australian economic conditions since the beginning of this year it would be helpful to Australia's national interest if I were to speculate in this matter. All I will say is this: As distinct from the incoherent and disastrous economic policies that were followed under the management and direction of the honourable member who has asked the question, this Government will pursue economic policies which will ensure the best possible outcome for Australia in all areas of the economy, including the levels of interest rates.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the outcome of the Government's recent bilateral talks on arms control and disarmament with the United States and the Soviet Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly I cannot go into great detail about what were confidential discussions, but I can say that the Government regarded both series of talks as extremely useful. It goes without saying that of course our relations with the United States are so very much closer, but we believe that a credible arms control and disarmament policy required Australia to maintain a practical and effective dialogue with the Soviet Union as well. We agreed with both super-powers on the need for deep cuts in nuclear weapons and we urged that every effort be taken to avoid an arms race in space. We also emphasised the importance of the horizontal proliferation aspects of the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the need for a successful outcome of the review conference of the NPT later this year. We also stressed the importance of commencing substantive work on a comprehensive test ban treaty.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be pleasing for the House to note that we found a very substantial measure of common ground on the issue of chemical weapons, particularly with the United States of America. We agreed to co-operate with the United States in developing its proposal for reciprocal visits by both super-powers to each other's test sites, and we will be consulting further with the Americans on this subject. It is also worth noting in passing that, as agreed during the recent visits by Mr Hu Yaobang, we will shortly be consulting with the Chinese about a similar round of talks to be held with them in the near future.

It is in this context that I note that last week-this must have come as a great surprise to a great number of Australians-the Liberal Party of Australia found peace. It discovered peace, very characteristically. It had done a little polling and found what we knew and what had been reflected in our policy for a very long time; namely, that the issues of peace are of importance to the people of Australia. The Liberals, having done some polling, found that issue to be important, and so they discovered peace.

Characteristically, the new campaign on their newly found issue was launched on 27 April by the honourable member for Bennelong, who found a new campaign front on which to wage war on the Leader of the Opposition. It was not until a few days later, on 1 May that the Leader of the Opposition weighed in with a statement, as honourable members would have noted, regarding a video with the intriguing title of 'Peace, the Liberal Way'. If this is a case of 'you have seen the film, now read the book', the Australian public will certainly be presented with a very slim volume because the Liberal and National parties have absolutely no credibility in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been infiltrated by the SWP.

—They may well have been. It is well known that during times of international tension the Opposition forces have ardently and unfailingly sought to embroil this country in confrontation and conflict for their own divisive, internal Australian domestic political purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Cheap!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all right for honourable members opposite to say 'cheap' but the facts speak for themselves, because ironically--
—Madam Acting Speaker, I take a point of order. I wonder why the Prime Minister has taken troops out of the Sinai.
—Order! There is no point of order. Please do not raise frivolous points of order.

—Ironically, the Liberal Party chose to give the Australian people the benefit of its views on the subject of peace and disarmament in the week of the tenth anniversary of the fall of Saigon. The record of the Liberal Party during the Vietnam war epitomises totally its lack of credibility and responsibility on the issues of peace and war. It should be remembered with shame that it sought at any cost to commit the United States to a land war in Asia. The Liberals cynically used young conscripted Australians, to whom they denied the vote it will be recalled, as tokens for their purpose of seeking to involve the United States in a land war in Asia. At critical junctions of the war they inevitably argued in favour of escalation and against negotiations. Never let it be forgotten that they sought to deceive the Australian people into believing the fantasy that the ultimate enemy of Australia in Vietnam was China. That was the extent of the deception to which the Liberal Party was prepared to go in this matter. The Australian people should never forget that the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party of Australia were both Ministers who involved Australia in that deception. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was a member of the Government involved in that exercise. None of them, in the whole period since then, have uttered a single word to suggest that they have ever had a second thought about the way they involved this country and our young people in that war. Madam Acting Speaker, when one recalls that record in those circumstances-the way they manipulated the people of Australia for those obscene purposes-is it any wonder that the people of Australia will regard with contempt this latter day discovery by these people of the cause of peace?

—Will the Prime Minister guarantee that the Government will support full discounting of wage indexation for the effect on the consumer price index of any indirect tax increases resulting from taxation reform?

—Both the Treasurer and I have made it perfectly clear that in the conduct of the economic policy of this country we will ensure that policies are undertaken and decisions made which will guarantee the welfare of this country and will guarantee what the previous Government was never able to guarantee. What this Government has done in two years is to restore economic growth at low levels of inflation. An integral part of the capacity of this Government to rescue Australia from the economic disaster inflicted upon it by the Opposition when in government has been the accord with the trade union movement. It has served this country well. It has produced high levels of growth and has halved the levels of inflation which we inherited from the people on the other side of the House. Central to the capacity of this Government to produce those results has been our prices and incomes policy. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has conceded that one of the reasons why the previous Government made such an indescribable mess of the Australian economy was that it did not have such a policy. That is the advantage that we on this side of the House have over those on the other side of the House. It is because of our capacity to have a sensible and relevant incomes policy that we have been able to produce the goods. We will continue to do that throughout this year and the years ahead, both in relation to general economic policy and in regard to tax policy in particular.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPUBLIC OF KOREA: MINISTERIAL TRADE TALKS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Reports in the Australian Press indicate that the Minister for Trade, during his recent visit to the Republic of Korea, received some assurances in respect of Australian raw materials trade. Can the Minister confirm this and elaborate on it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie for his question. It is true that there were reports in the Australian Press-not nearly enough of them as far as I am concerned-on the results of--
—You used to get better coverage, John.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.
—So did the honourable member for O'Connor; he used to get editorials.
—Order! The Minister will ignore the interjections.

—The relationship between Australia and the Republic of Korea is a very important one and has the potential to become even more important as the Korean industrial expansion continues apace. Already, Korea is our fifth largest market and it has the capacity to become an even more important market for us. There have been difficulties in recent times, however, relating partly to Korea's complaints about its access to our market and various threats to disrupt the trade between us. Therefore, my visit took place against a background of an essentially strong and promising relationship which had been subject to some minor friction in recent times.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the discussions that I had with my counterpart in Korea, we now have assurances both from the Government of Korea and from the major purchasers-the steelmaker POSCO and the electricity utility KEPCO-that in the future raw material contracts will be settled between Korea and Australia purely on the basis of quality and price and will not be subject to any retaliation measures. Also, the Korean Minister for Trade assured me that he would clear the way for an early resumption of negotiations on contracts for raw materials between the Korean and Australian parties. For the first time, the Koreans agreed to consult Australia on the question of beef demand and supply in Korea, which will not only pave the way for an early warning for the Australian industry of the reopening of the beef market in Korea but also ensure that the Australian industry will be the first suppliers approached by the Koreans when they decide to reopen their market for beef.

There have been some difficulties confronting the Koreans in their sales to Australia, largely due, I suspect, to the depreciation of the Australian dollar, which is something that they, of course, understand. I have undertaken to look at what other matters might be affecting their trade and to accelerate the present normal values cases affecting radial tyres and steel pipes and tubes.

As a result of these discussions, we have put the relationship, which is basically very firm and promising into the future, on an even firmer foundation. In order to prevent the recurrence of the kind of friction that has occurred in recent times, it has been agreed that the work of the Joint Trade Committee, which exists to look at these matters, be elevated. That Committee will meet again in September, in advance of a further meeting between the Korean Minister for Trade and me either later this year or early next year. We will thereby ensure a better understanding of the issues in this important relationship and that when difficulties arise they will be dealt with promptly and frankly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to his statement in respect of spending cuts, that the original Forward Estimates have been affected by the volatility of the currency, and the fact that they are normally subject to other non-policy changes such as the economic growth rate. Will the Prime Minister assure the House that the forthcoming statement on expenditure cuts will clearly show what part of the cuts is due to the policy changes being proposed and what part is due to non-policy change such as the depreciation of the Australian dollar?

—The Forward Estimates will be released on Thursday of this week. The releasing of those Forward Estimates, in conjunction with the statements that will be made by the Treasurer on the evening of 14 May, will enable the honourable member to ascertain clearly the answer to his question. I repeat what I have said before: All members of this House and the people of Australia will be able to appreciate the reality of the more than $1 billion cuts that will be announced by the Treasurer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport. I refer to the announcement of the Australian land transport program. I ask the Minister: First, does the program provide a co-ordinated approach to the development of future land transport networks? Secondly, does the program confirm the strong commitment of the Federal Government to main road development as outlined in the pre-election commitment of the Government? Thirdly, does the development of the Australian land transport program tie in with the commitment of the Government to developing closer relationships with local government in the implementation of its programs and policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The Australian land transport program legislation to be introduced tomorrow will show the Parliament the co-ordinated approach that this Government is taking to the funding of all forms of land transport. By that I mean the building and maintenance of roads, road safety promotion and road safety research and the provision of a limited amount of money for the upgrading of interstate main line rail networks. That approach is something which has long been lacking in this nation. It also provides a basis for a proper cost recovery approach to land transport in the country.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to be able to say that that legislation also confirms our commitment to the development of our road and rail systems in a co-ordinated, complementary fashion, rather than a straight-out alternative fashion. It is not a matter of road or rail transport; it is a matter of road and rail transport, each form of transport carrying out the task to which it is economically, socially and technically best suited. In that way we will get the most efficient transport system. With the most efficient transport system we will be better able to exploit market opportunities abroad and we will be better able to exploit our manufacturing and economic opportunities and we will be able to provide more jobs at a faster rate in this nation.

We have made special provisions for local government in the Australian land transport program. As the honourable member properly mentioned in regard to the very effective role he foreshadowed for local government, we are ensuring that the level of Federal expenditure on roads for local government will be maintained in real terms. Next year's provision will maintain this year's expenditure in real terms. From there on, the indexation of the funds provided under the legislation will ensure that local government's interests are protected.

We have taken the view that local government has a narrower financial base. It has growing burdens placed upon it and is the least able of the three levels of government to expand that revenue base to carry out the tasks which it is called upon to perform. If we look at the legislation we see that next year we will be providing $258m for work on local council roads. For New South Wales that is an increase of 5 per cent, for Victoria an increase of more than 6 per cent, for Queensland an increase of almost 6 per cent, for Western Australia an increase of 5.6 per cent, for South Australia an increase of 6 per cent and for Tasmania an increase of 4 per cent. In total that $258m is a 60 per cent increase of Federal expenditure on local roads on the last full year's Budget of the Fraser Government.

I commend the honourable member for the work that he is doing and for the representations he makes on behalf of local government. I say again to the House that the Australian land transport program fulfils the major election promise of the Prime Minister to maintain the greatest road building and road construction program ever undertaken in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Communications give an assurance to non-metropolitan Australians that on the introduction of Aussat Pty Ltd television services regionalism on a State and local basis will not be subjugated to centralised interests?

—I thank the honourable member for Gippsland for his question. As the honourable member and other honourable members will be aware, last year the policy of the Government on this matter was announced in this Parliament. The Government remains committed to existing policies concerning the provision of commercial radio and television to the remote areas of Australia and, in particular, the remote commercial television service known as RCTS. However, unlike governments in the past, we are also concerned to see that those areas receive an extension of services beyond RCTS. For that reason the Forward Development Unit was set up within the Department of Communications to look at the first steps in the equalisation of services. One of the most important steps in moving towards equalisation will be the supplementary licence scheme. That has to move more quickly than was expected and this Government has a commitment to do that. But in answer to the first part of the question, the Government remains committed to existing policies.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment to recent Press reports casting doubts on the Government's continued support and, in particular, its taxation support for the film industry. Are the reports correct? What is the Government's policy in regard to the continuation of support, in particular taxation support, for the Australian film industry? Can he cite any recent successes of that support for the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I am surprised at the way in which this issue has surfaced over the past few months because I do not think there is another issue upon which both the Prime Minister and I have repeatedly stated or reaffirmed the Government's position regarding Division 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It has been one of the resounding successes that this Government has had. I am very proud to say that in the last 18 months expenditure on television and film production has increased from $55m to $130m. We are now making approximately 27 to 30 feature films per year, about seven or eight television movies and about 80 documentaries. I see no reason, on the indications that I have available to me, why we will not continue at that rate in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: I pay tribute to members of the Opposition for the work that they did in the Australian film industry when they were in government. It is now going through the most stable period in its history. The Prime Minister has reaffirmed his commitment to the 10BA provisions for the life of the Parliament and we have reaffirmed it; yet we are constantly being asked to reaffirm the situation. The honourable member also asked about the successes in the film industry. At the Cannes film festival, Australia had two films in the final 14 nominations-Bliss and The Coca Cola Kid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going?

—I would like to go to Cannes, but the Prime Minister thought that I was needed more here. My predecessor went. This is an outstanding performance by the film industry. We can only hope that the two nominations are successful. If not, it is still a great honour to have two films in the final 14 films at Cannes. If the opportunity presents itself, I hope to show those films to honourable members in the foreseeable future.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industry. Will the Government's proposed dairy industry plan encourage the State governments to impose additional regulations on the industry unlike the proposals of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, which would avoid this difficulty? How does the Minister propose to implement his dairy marketing plan if any State government refuses to collect the all milk levy? What aspects of the Minister's dairy plan will be discussed at the announced meeting on Thursday with the Victorian Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs and Victorian dairy industry officials?

—The honourable member should not worry about the dairy industry, by golly, because we know what we are doing. He should just wait to see. He should take our word on this. We are not going to be stood over by thugs and bullies, these people putting on milk blockades in Victoria and now in the Australian Capital Territory; no way at all. What the honourable member should be worried about is his failure to understand the present dairy arrangements, the disastrous socialist Sinclair plan. Once he understands them-if ever he does, by gosh-perhaps he will stop asking silly questions. The honourable member is running around like a chook with two right legs.

—Is the Minister for Science able to advise the House about the prospects of collaboration between Australia and Israel in agricultural research, bearing in mind that Australia is the driest continent and that Israel is continually confronted with the problem of providing itself with an adequate water supply?

—I had the benefit of discussions in Israel in April with President Herzog, Prime Minister Peres, Research Minister Patt, government departments, universities and the Weizmann Institute of Science about matters of common scientific interest. Inevitably, water was the dominant subject. Israel is currently using 10 per cent more water each year than the natural replenishment rate and this raises issues of national survival for Israel. Israel is working on the use of salt water crops in agriculture-asparagus is one example-and on using biotechnology to develop mutant strains of salt resistant plants, for example tomatoes. It is also working on the use of industrial and urban waste water in farming. Miniature apple trees, growing to about a metre high, have been developed. They produce large amounts of fruit and consume relatively little water--
—Big apples?

—Yes, they have big apples, but the trees are discarded after two years. The process of converting sea water into fresh water now being developed in Saudi Arabia is not open to Israel because of the enormous cost. The Israelis are very anxious for Australian agricultural and water scientists to visit their country as a matter of urgency and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation would be eager to co-operate providing that appropriate sources of funding can be found-outside the Budget, I assure the Treasurer. I will be discussing this with my colleagues, the Minister for Resources and Energy and the Minister for Primary Industry, who have primary responsibility for water and farming. We will, of course, be anxious to promote technology transfer in this area of acute common interest.

—Can the Minister for Social Security confirm that a pensioner couple on a farm who lose their pension due to the assets test can sell their farm, put all their assets into an expensive city home and qualify for a pension? If so, will the Minister alter the pensions assets test to allow these pensioners to stay on their farms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assets test was designed in such a way as to be equitable and fair. The test must be fundamentally administered in a way that does not make distinctions between people living in rural as opposed to urban situations. Of course there are special characteristics in urban areas, just as there are special characteristics in rural areas. The Government took that into account when it designed the assets test. I believe that if there is one thing that is fundamental to any test or to any measure that the Government introduces that affects people's assets and capital, it is a commitment on the part of every member of the Parliament that the home ought to be excluded. That has been a fundamental principle which has been applied to the assets test. It is one that I believe has worked overall in terms of fairness, wherever people live. While it may be true that some people in urban areas live in very expensive homes, it is also true that some people in the country areas live in expensive homes. The valuations of homes on rural properties took into account not simply the context of their farming neighbourhoods but also the context of the urban values within that region of the country.

ANSWER.PARA: It seems to me that underlying the honourable member's question is the suggestion not that people in rural areas ought to be treated equitably and on the same basis as people in the urban areas are treated but that people in rural areas ought to get special treatment. Of course that is fundamental to the ideology of the National Party of Australia because it is a party of special interests and it unashamedly pursues policies which suggest that people in rural areas ought to be treated in some special way. But I would not have thought the same thing would have applied to members of the Liberal Party of Australia. I would have thought that people in the Liberal Party would have sought to achieve a more rational approach than that which is implied in the honourable member's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. What positive economic benefit should flow for our nation following the recent devaluation of the Australian dollar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I thank the honourable member for Lowe for his question. I can be brief in my answer to this question. The benefits are obvious. The people on the other side of the House representing rural Australia-we have a number of them on this side of the House and we will have more after the next election-have obviously welcomed the devaluation because it will mean that both our exporters of rural products and our exporters of mineral products will have a welcome increase in their income levels as a result. It is not so obviously and frequently recognised that the devaluation will have very significant benefits also for our manufacturing industry because it will make it more competitive both on export markets and against imports. I am able to say to the House that as a result of discussions with a number of business leaders engaged actively in the manufacturing sector, what is obviously true in theory is also being worked out in practice. I have been informed that a number of export markets are opening up for areas of our manufacturing industry which, until the devaluation, it had not regarded as being within its range. So all sectors of our economy should benefit from the devaluation.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said before, the challenge and responsibility for government is to ensure that these benefits are not dissipated by a secondary inflationary spiral. We are committed to ensuring that the necessary action will be taken to prevent that outcome. In the event, the devaluation of the Australian dollar should be seen as providing a very significant opportunity to enterprise in this country. I believe it is capable of rising to that challenge and we, in government, will ensure that it has every opportunity to take advantage of that challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to yet another blockade to commence today. Does the Government intend to protect the people of Queensland against the trade unions' new transport blockade of that State? In particular, will it act to ensure that Commonwealth services including mail, for which this Labor Government is responsible, continue to be provided to the people of Queensland or does the Government intend again to endorse implicitly the unions' guerrilla attacks on Queenslanders; in other words, to do nothing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no endorsement by this Government of the campaign of industrial action. What we have said is that the unions should not be taking industrial action but rather should be seeking to achieve a resolution of this matter in other ways. In particular, we have sought to provide a basis by which there can be negotiations between the trade union movement and the Government to achieve that resolution.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of action by Australia Post, a ban on mail to Queensland yesterday led to a notification by the Government to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of the existence of an industrial dispute. That matter will be proceeded with within the Arbitration Commission.

Let me say to the Opposition that the situation remains one in which the resolution of this whole matter is very much in the hands of the Queensland Government. It is not a matter which will be resolved by actions taken by this Government against unions which are placing bans. Let me say that the most likely result of adopting the course advocated by the Opposition would be a great widening of existing bans and industrial confrontation right across this nation. The Opposition Leader knows, as an ex-Minister for Industrial Relations who used to say some reasonably sensible things in this area, that that would be the result of the action he is now advocating this Government should take.

We are not going to go down that path. We will seek to resolve this matter in the way in which we have so far pursued it. We are continuing to try to achieve a situation in which negotiations can take place. I believe that steps which are in train may give us an opportunity to bring those negotiations about in the not too distant future.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
National Flag
To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisified with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mr Peter Fisher and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag

The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petitions of certain undersigned Australian and overseas students respectfully showeth that:
1. The Overseas student program brings in a multitude of cultural, political and educational benefits as well as a net financial gain of $A5 million p.a., in foreign exchange. (Ref: Goldring Report)

2. Overseas students are under financial constraints. Most depend on their families for this financial support. The Goldring Report found 62 per cent of Overseas students come from families with annual combined parental income of less than $A15,000.

3. The imposition of high Overseas student charges will deprive many overseas students from getting a tertiary education and qualification in Australia despite their academic abilities. High charges will determine education in Australia for Overseas students on economic grounds.
4. The imposition of sudden and drastic increases in visa charges will also particularly disadvantage those current students, many of whom will be forced to discontinue their studies.
5. Overseas students do not displace local students. They represent a mere 3.4 per cent of tertiary students. (Goldring Report)
6. The fluctuations and uncertainty in Overseas students policy has led to uncertainty, stress and fear in Overseas students.
Your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray that:

1. The Government re-affirm a commitment to its policy that supports the social and economic development of people and institutions in developing countries through access to Australia's education and training resources.
2. The Government formulate a consistent and considerate policy concerning Overseas students.
3. The Government reconsider, as a matter of urgency, the legislation of such a high increase in visa charges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross and Mr Hodges.
