But the Government has taken those decisions and one has to accept that he fully supports decisions that have been taken by the Government. But back in November 1981 financial deregulation was not nearly as fashionable as it is now. There were plenty of people who looked back on the experience of the 1950s and 1960s and came to the rather simplistic conclusion that that period of 20 years had given us unrivalled and quite remarkable prosperity-a fact that was acknowledged at the National Economic Summit Conference in 1983 by the present Treasurer when he said that the 1950s and 1960s were periods of great prosperity. In fact the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), who spoke to the matter of public importance, said that we now have profit levels back to what they were in the 1950s and 1960s, as though the 1950s and 1960s were the great decades of economic endeavour and achievement in Australia.

Coming back to November 1981, I think the problem was that a lot of people opposed financial deregulation and a lot of people were scared of financial deregulation because they thought that the reason why the 1950s and 1960s had been periods of great prosperity was that they were years in which governments intervened, governments regulated and governments controlled our financial and economic sectors. The fact is that they were periods of economic prosperity and growth irrespective of government intervention, despite government intervention in many areas and despite government controls. In November 1981 there were not too many people who were very interested in the cause of financial deregulation. There were plenty of people-certainly all the members of the Labor Party and, to be fair, a number of people on the coalition side of politics-who were willing to argue that the whole idea of significant deregulation of the Australian financial system was something that ought to be put completely aside and something that ought to be completely forgotten.

Circumstances have now changed although the change in the attitude of members of the Labor Party did not occur until they came into government. I think it is worth recording that not only did the then shadow Treasurer, the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Gellibrand, express very strong opposition to the whole philosophic and ideological basis of the Campbell report and say that it was guilty of social blindness and insensitivity, that it was naive and that it was talking nonsense but also, when the present Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, replaced him as shadow Treasurer in late January 1983, he immediately picked up the same rhetoric. I know that, to many who have read over the last few months of the contribution of the present Treasurer and praise that he deservedly got in that time for his work in deregulating the financial system, it is a matter of some interest to reflect on what he had to say on 24 January 1983. It really is thoroughly ironic that on that date, just after he had become the shadow Treasurer, he had this to say:

And once the foreign banks are here they will not be interested in retail banking, they won't be interested in small business or farm finance or housing finance, indeed they won't even have a branch structure where one would facilitate the arrangement of such finance, so the likelihood is they will be looking after the large slabs of wholesale banking to the top echelon to the corporate sector, and it would be very soon thereafter that our Trading banks require the Australian Government to free it of the controls, the regulations which now provide this finance to the retail end of the market at deferential rates.

That is almost a museum piece of the troglodytal thinking that used to dominate the Australian Labor Party on that issue. That sort of sentiment was not expressed in New York a couple of weeks ago when the Treasurer was there. It is to the national good that he has put away the foolish notions of this political childhood on that particular issue and that he has now adopted more sane and more sensible attitudes. It is interesting to reflect once again, as we on this side of the House have had occasion to reflect, that one of the judgments that are made in the long term about the political contribution of people in this Parliament to political life in Australia is the extent to which they demonstrate responsible behaviour both in government and in opposition. It is all very well for the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others in the present Government to run around patting themselves on the back and saying: 'Aren't we terrific because we have let in all of these banks and we have done all of these marvellous things'. When it was not so fashionable to support deregulation and when it was a lot harder politically, where were they? They were in with the best of them stirring up all the primeval opposition and all the old community suspicions about these things.

This is not a time to be uncharitable because the Opposition and I are very pleased that we are to have a more open and more competitive banking sector as a result of the decision that was announced by the Treasurer a few weeks ago. For the record, I remind the House that the entry of foreign banks into Australia has in fact been delayed for over two years by the action of this Government. It appears to have been forgotten by many people that the former Government announced a definitive decision to admit foreign banks into Australia early in 1983. Predictably, as I indicated earlier, that decision was denounced and lambasted as being in the interest of wicked overseas capitalist and monetary interests and to the detriment of little Australians and all that was good and pure about Australian commercial, corporate and, I dare say, family life as well. It was roundly denounced by the present Treasurer but, of course, the Damascus road has got very crowded indeed when it comes to financial deregulation.

I am very happy to say that the present Treasurer has now adopted the policies that I supported both in government and in opposition and has put aside his rather old fashioned hostility to foreign banks. Responding to that old adage that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, I should be mightily impressed and flattered that a policy that was called social blindness by the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and denounced by the present Treasurer when he was in opposition has now been adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a lot of disciples.

—They have gone out and multiplied, if one can pursue that biblical analogy, quite a lot over the last couple of years. It is very interesting that they have only gone out and multiplied since it became a little more fashionable to believe in financial deregulation. Two or three years ago nobody wanted it.
—Don't get too carried away.

—The honourable member for Melbourne says that I should not get carried away about the fashionability of deregulation. That is a marvellously interesting statement. These debates would be no good without the contributions of the honourable member for Melbourne. A couple of other things about the very interesting history of this issue ought to be said in this debate. This gives me an opportunity to say something about the committee whose recommendations ultimately led to the decision that we are now debating. I refer to the Campbell Committee of Inquiry. Many famous committees have been established by governments of both political persuasions in Australia over the years, such as the Campbell Committee, the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, the Vernon Committee of Economic Inquiry established by the Menzies Government and the royal commission into banking that was established in 1936. One could go on and on. We are going to have the report of another quite important committee in the next couple of days, the Hancock Committee of Review into the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. I do not think that will be too replete with deregulation but we will wait to see whether there has been a Damascus road conversion on the subject of labour market deregulation, because if there has that would be very remarkable.

SPEECH.PARA: Going back to the Campbell Committee, I think one thing can truthfully be said-this is no reflection on the calibre of the people who sat on other great committees of inquiry in Australia-that is, that the Campbell inquiry has probably turned out to be the most successful of all the great committees of inquiry that have been established by any Australian government in our history. Now that we look back on what has been done in this area, we find that just about all of the major recommendations either have been substantially implemented or are on the path to being implemented. It is a matter of some pride on this side of the House that a committee that was set up in the face of sniping and of criticism that it was unbalanced, one-sided and that it was too ideologically pure and too committed to free market principles-a reflection on the judgment that was made by the former Government at the time that this Committee was set up in 1979-has been so outstandingly successful in having its recommendations implemented.

In that context, it is very interesting to reflect, if I may for a moment, on an editorial that was written, no doubt, by that well known political and economic commentator, Maximilian Walsh, who was then the Managing Editor of the Australian Financial Review, on 19 January 1979, the day after I had announced the establishment of the Campbell inquiry. Mr Walsh reflected on the composition of the Committee. After welcoming it and writing quite a generous editorial about the then Government's decision, he lamented the fact that I had not put, as he called it, a Ben Chifley on the Committee of Inquiry. Mr Walsh took me to task for not having diluted the Committee, so to speak, with a representative of the trade union movement or a representative of, as he called it, the other point of view or the other side of politics.

I do not in any way denigrate the memory of Ben Chifley; he occupies a very honoured place not only in Labor Party history in Australia but in Australian political history generally. What has come out of the Campbell report and the fact that so much of it has been accepted is perhaps a lesson to all of us that the idea that when a committee is established every point of view should be put on it is not such a sound idea after all. To get the best results we first of all ought to have a clear idea of the general direction we want to go. Having done that, we pick four or five people who really believe in going in that general direction. Governments on both sides have made the mistake, having identified a problem, of appointing a committee while not having a clear idea of where they wanted to end up. They appoint a representative of every point of view to the committee and they think that out of that they are going to get some marvellous solutions that will satisfy everybody. The reality is that often out of that process we get a solution that does not really satisfy anybody at all.

Having made that reflection, I also take the opportunity, as I have done in the past, of acknowledging on behalf of the coalition parties the enormous contribution that was made by the late Sir Keith Campbell. From my personal acquaintance with him I can say that he was one of the finest members of the Australian business community I have ever met. He was a very hard working man. He never said no to doing another job for the community or for the Government. I have not the slightest doubt that one of the reasons for his premature death not long after the change of government in 1983, after his attendance at the National Economic Summit Conference, was in fact the enormous work load he undertook. But of all the things that he did in his public career none will be a more enduring monument to him than the report that bears his name and which has been the philosophical mainspring for so much of what has happened in this area over the last few years.

This debate is therefore an opportunity to reflect a little on the way in which attitudes have changed within large sections of the Labor Party on this issue. That change is a very good thing. I have not the slightest doubt that ultimately the final interest rate controls-that is, interest rate controls on housing loans-will go. It is only a matter of time. It is appropriate that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) is at the table. Although he and some of his mates in the Left grin as much to say 'That is what you think', it is interesting to note that the other day when the Treasurer announced the abolition of controls on small business loans under $100,000 he used the argument-a very sound argument, I might say-to justify their removal which is precisely the argument that ultimately will be used by him to justify the removal of interest rate controls on housing loans. That argument is that if, when we have upward pressure on interest rates, we control the rate at which banks can charge interest on money they lend out we will impair their capacity to get money in the first place, so we will have the old scarcity problem arising and the only way we can solve that, of course, is to decontrol interest rates. It is only a matter of time before that occurs. Let me say on behalf of the Opposition that if the Government moves in that direction it will not be the subject of criticism from us; we would support such a move.

Having said a couple of complimentary things about the Government and having acknowledged the change of heart that has occurred on the part of the Treasurer and many others as far as financial deregulation is concerned, let me get on to one other area of deregulation. As this Bill largely concerns deregulatory matters, it is appropriate that I say something about it. I refer to the next area, in fact the new frontier, of deregulation in Australia-that is, deregulation of the labour market. We have talked a bit about going out and multiplying, but I will believe in miracles if the Australian Labor Party ever embraces deregulation of the labor market. If there is one great blot on the economic escutcheon in Australia at present it is our highly centralised labour market.

Just as I am ready to acknowledge the good sense of the Government in moving towards deregulation of the financial system, as it has done over the last two years, I am equally critical of the way in which during that same period it has regulated and made far more rigid and controlled the labour market in Australia. I am not the only person to say that there is some incompatibility between a regulated labour market and a deregulated financial system. I say to the honourable members who sit opposite that this will not be the last time they hear about that dichotomy. There are two remarkable things about the Hawke Government's decision in December 1983 to float the Australian dollar. Firstly, given Labor's long history of interventionist attitudes towards the financial system, it is remarkable that the Hawke Government, to its credit, took that decision. The other remarkable thing is that I do not think many people in the Government or in the Australian Labor Party's rank and file realise the implications of that decision. A floating exchange rate exposes the economy of a country, in a far more direct, immediate and brutal manner, to the economic judgments of the rest of the world. Those judgments are evident now. Incidentally, this would still happen under an administered exchange rate but it would happen in a more indirect manner. We have experienced for the first time over the last few months the volatility that comes from a floating exchange rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The former Prime Minister would not let you float the dollar.

—I am not expressing the views of any member of the last Government other than myself on this subject. All I can say to the Minister and to others opposite is that over the last few months we have seen the effects of that volatility, and many people in the Labor Party who watched the decision of the Government to float the dollar in December 1983 and who said that it seemed like a good idea are now starting to realise what it all means. It is now sinking in. That is why the Government is in such a terrible bind over the question of the discounting of wages. What it cannot explain away in economic terms is that if we have a depreciation of our currency the country is made poorer whether we like it or not, and if one section of the community says that despite that national impoverishment it wants real wage maintenance, it is saying to the rest of the community that they have to cop an even greater reduction in their living standards to maintain the living standards of that particular section. That is what Simon Crean and Bill Kelty are saying at present, and that is why the Government has been hooked on this dilemma right from the beginning of this session, when the Prime Minister was asked a question on this subject and said: 'You are right economically but I cannot do it industrially'. Then the Treasurer said: 'Hang on, Bob, we might have to do it or the business community will not like us any more'. They have been backing and filling and dodging and squirming on this issue ever since because they cannot face that reality. As the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) said in the matter of public importance debate that has just concluded, the strength of the trade union movement on that particular issue makes it impossible for them.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to my theme of a moment ago. I will really believe in miracles if the Labor Party can embrace deregulation of the labour market. Now that deregulation of the financial system is substantially completed-the Labor Party has played a significant, proper and creditworthy role in that-we must ask whether it really does believe in deregulation. It does not. My friend the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) shakes his head and indicates that no, they do not really believe in it. What he is really saying is: 'Financial deregulation is all right provided it does not cause any ripples, letting these foreign banks in is probably okay now because everybody seems to go along with letting in some foreign banks and we do not really like the Australian banks anyway'. That is the attitude of the Labor Party. The Treasurer made that fairly clear at the New South Wales ALP Conference a couple of years ago, when he had a few choice things to say about the existing trading banks in Australia.

Let us really see how good members of the Labor Party are on deregulation, see how they react to deregulation of the labour market, because that is the new frontier of deregulation. If they really believe in deregulation, if they really want to peel away some of the restrictions, particularly on the small business sector, if they really want to ask themselves why it is that over the last couple of years eight million to nine million new jobs have been created in the United States while in the whole of western Europe, with an equivalent population, no new jobs have been generated, if they want to ask themselves why it is that the growth potential that exists in the small business and service sector of Australia is not being fully realised, if they want to find out why it is that there are renewed concerns about the impact of a system of rigid full wage indexation in Australia, they have to recognise the one very obvious answer, which is that we have a highly centralised, rigidified, over-regulated labour market in Australia. It has been made infinitely worse by the actions of this Government and, although it has taken off certain controls in the financial area, it has confounded the effectiveness of that by adding still further controls in the labour market area.

Until such time as the Labor Party embraces the need for deregulation of the labour market it has absolutely no right to lay claim to any really full-blooded commitment to the deregulation of the Australian economy. I believe that over the next couple of years this will be the area of great debate in discussions on economic management in Australia. Once again, it is an area that it was not terribly fashionable to talk about a short while ago but it is amazing that over the last six or nine months a great many more people have started to take up the cause of deregulation of the labour market. It will become a far more popular cause to espouse. There is a very obvious reason for that, and that is that people have looked at what has happened in other countries. They have observed the astonishing vitality of the economy of the United States which draws in large measure from the great flexibility of the American labour market. That is the new frontier of deregulation in Australia. It is a cause that we on this side of the House full-bloodedly espouse. I wonder whether the Labor Party might, in the fullness of time, as it did on the question of the financial system, go along the Damascus road on the deregulation of the labour market.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are in this place from time to time no doubt some moments when the luck of the draw brings honourable members into a debate after the person they would most like to follow, and in my case the luck of the draw has come up today because I am delighted to follow the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The first point I make is that the reason he is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is that he was the Treasurer and he failed. His policies failed. That was why our Government was elected and that is why we are now in the position of implementing some of these practical reforms in our society. That is the reason why he is now being compared with our Treasurer (Mr Keating), the world's best Treasurer. If the honourable member for Bennelong would like to listen for a while I might outline for him some of the mechanics of the financial sector in Australia so that if he does have another chance he might get it right.

SPEECH.PARA: The Banks (Shareholdings) Amendment Bill 1985 culminates several years of consideration, as the honourable member for Bennelong said, of major reforms to the Australian financial system. It follows, as he said, the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and it also follows, in my view very significantly, the report of the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System which followed the inquiry carried out by Campbell. The Bill forms part of the Government's overall economic strategy to restructure and reform a number of our major industries. It is a consistent and coherent approach to deregulation, which has impacted in several industries. It is now working through the agriculture industry, the steel industry and the motor vehicle industry, our relationships between Commonwealth and State governments and, of course, in terms of the subject of this debate, the finance and banking sectors.

I take this opportunity to mention a couple of points that were outlined by the Treasurer on the impact that this Bill will make because it encourages the establishment of new banks in Australia. These are expected by the Government to bring substantial benefits to the Australian community through the development of a more innovative, efficient and competitive financial sector. That will lead to a higher rate of economic growth and a higher standard of living for the people of Australia. They are the benefits that we perceive through the introduction of this Bill. It comes from a broader perspective and it relates above all to an understanding of the principles of economic management, not just rhetoric and philosophy. In my maiden speech in this place I made reference to the fact that so many of the policies of honourable members opposite failed because they were bereft of expertise. Nothing that I have heard from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this debate in any way changes my view.

As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, the concept of this Bill goes back to the establishment of the Campbell inquiry. He made mention of the fact that this legislation could be several years-I believe two, three or four-behind its time. The reason for that is a mistake that he made when the original Campbell inquiry was established in 1979 because at the heart of the terms of reference are the following words:
. . . the importance of the efficiency of the financial system for the Government's free enterprise objectives and broad goals for national economic prosperity . . .

The problem with that term of reference was that it espoused a free enterprise objective, but it was tied up in a net of mumbo jumbo and regulation. The honourable member did not have a practical approach to unravelling the Australian economy and placed the Campbell inquiry in a position of having to analyse in a framework of pure competition. If honourable members understand the meaning of that they would then understand that the findings of the Campbell inquiry had to come down within the terms of a pure supply and demand financial sector with no real reference to the social implications of various changes. At that time, just after the Hawke Labor Government was elected, the Australian Financial Review commented on the decision of the Government to establish the Martin committee to carry out an investigation into the social implications of the findings of the Campbell inquiry. The Australian Financial Review at that time did not quite have it right. Its editorial said that the task force will not do:

. . . much more than provide a . . . forum for the regulators to express their opposition to the deregulation proposed by the Campbell Report. It is likely to be a mere political exercise rather than a useful contribution to our understanding of the matters-
I was moved at that time to write to the editor of the Financial Review and in my letter I said:
. . . the Enquiry--
that is, the Campbell inquiry--
chose to adopt a 'pure competition' model as the key assumption. In doing so it rendered many of its conclusions invalid from the point of view of practical government.
In a rare moment of perspicacity I went on:
. . . the proposals favouring the introduction of foreign banking licences assume that our banking sector can withstand foreign competition-
That referred to 1982 and 1983. I continued:

Our banking people may even believe this themselves. However, if it were not to be the case and our banking sector found itself in the predicament now faced by the manufacturing sector there would be cold comfort in knowing that 'true market factors were at work'. Given that the banking sector is a major employer . . . this is a risk we are not yet prepared to take.
I do not support the concept of indefinite propping up and protection. However, there are lessons to be learned from our recent experiences--
of the Australian economy--
and the government needs to be given time to absorb them.

That was the point of the Martin committee. Its work, in taking the Campbell Committee's findings and turning them into a social perspective that this Government could make workable, is the real reason why we are now able to introduce this legislation and successfully make these sorts of advances in deregulation.

That leads to our present position. In the introduction of the Bill and the introduction of foreign banking licences in Australia the Government has had to satisfy a number of concerns and we are pleased that they are being satisfied. We wanted to be satisfied that these changes would enhance employment opportunities. We wanted to be sure that there would be consultation with the unions on technological change, that the impact of new technology would cover health and safety issues, that there would be equal opportunity for women in the banking sector, that we would train Australians and give them skills in foreign banking expertise. These were all requirements that we made of banks that wanted to move into our sector. We did not want to open up the door and let them go for their lives and wipe out the Australian industry. We wanted to cover a number of key considerations. We were concerned that the corporate structure should fit our own structure and objectives, that Australian equity in these banks should be maintained and that the size of shareholdings provided for in the Bill should prevent foreign takeover or control-the sorts of things that the previous Government failed to provide for in its legislation.

I believe that the Bill is a major innovation and will be commended widely. I believe that the efforts of the Government in turning the rhetoric of pure competition into a practical working model within our community will be acknowledged in the future. The future of our financial markets and economy has much going for it as a result of the Government's initiatives.

I make special mention of the application by the Bank of China to be one of the new banks to be established in Australia. Its process of re-establishing its operations here follows from the initiatives of our Labor Government. I had the pleasure of attending the reception for the Secretary-General of the Chinese Communist Party, Mr Hu, and noticed that there is more and more talk and development now of the implications of foreign trade with China. In the early 1970s, when the previous Labor Government was looking at opening up initiatives with China, the benefits that would accrue to our economy from such a move were not something that those on the other side of the House could foresee. Through this Bill, the Bank of China will establish itself in Australia, and more trade initiatives will be opened up. Again, we will see great benefits from that in the future.

I believe that as a result of the impact of this legislation we will see increases in capital investment. These new banks will bring with them-they are required to bring with them-an injection of foreign capital that will lead to building industry stimulation as the banks build their new headquarters and branches. They will bring with them technology and infrastructure. They will create employment opportunities. They will assist us in developing ourselves as the major finance sector in the South West Pacific region. We will be nationally poised to take up this sort of role as a result of the initiatives of this Bill. What I like most about the Bill is that it means that we are bringing the Australian economy into its own in the world and in our own region. Through this Bill and through the things that will develop from it we are securing our independence, we are improving our sophistication and, above all, we are improving our skills and professionalism. The benefits of that will be seen in the latter part of this year and beyond.

The Bill will provide substantial new benefits within the community. It will mean that we will now have banking of sufficient size and expertise to offer effective competition with existing institutions. Through the national payments council we have ensured that the non-bank finance intermediaries in Australia now have access to wholesale banking arrangements. In other words, the monopoly and restrictive trade practices carried out by trading banks in Australia over many years have now been broken down. Services are being expanded. My credit union sent me a letter the other day telling me about a new plastic card and the sorts of things it now has access to, things that were denied such institutions for decades. They were not even allowed to operate cheque accounts because of a regulated, protected finance sector built up by those opposite under the Deputy Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer. As I said when I started my speech, it is a rare moment when one gets the opportunity to follow exactly the person one would like to follow in a debate. I have welcomed that opportunity. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice the desire of the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) to follow the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in this debate. Of course, he is following the Deputy Leader of the Opposition because the Labor Government, in introducing the Banks (Shareholdings) Amendment Bill 1985, is following the very important lead given by the Fraser Government, and by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: It gives me particular pleasure to support this Bill and to follow my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The Bill facilitates the establishment of new banks in Australia and puts into practice the statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 27 February this year. The establishment of the new banks will lead to the development of one of the service industries in our country. At a time when a number of manufacturing and other industries are suffering from a lack of competitiveness, it is good to see that some new industries are developing-developing in this case because of the Government's decision to move towards deregulation.

It is a pity, however, that in so many respects the Government is inconsistent and cannot see the interconnections between different policy areas. The Government's decision, good as it may be, is an ad hoc decision. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has pointed out, it does not flow through into a whole range of other policy areas, in particular, into the labour market. The Government appears to have been going down the road to Damascus and to have received some inspiration along that road which has shown it what the national interest truly is in some respects. However, suddenly, on the side of that road, the Government has seen its friends in the special interest groups waving from amongst the bushes and, particularly in respect of the labour market, threatening it. So, instead of continuing down the road to Damascus, as the Government should have been doing, it has walked off into the scrub and lost its way.

However, as I have said earlier, in this legislation the Government is certainly heading in the right direction. It has certainly taken the right decision. I particularly applaud the way the Government has decided to grant 16 licences to foreign banks instead of following the recommendation of the report of the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System to grant, if I recall correctly, four to six licences. At the time of the publication of the Martin report, when I was the Director of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, I put out a statement urging the Treasurer to disregard that recommendation of the Martin report and move towards the granting of many more licences. I am glad to say that the Treasurer was able to follow the recommendations that I, a number of other people in the business community and the Opposition gave him.

It is particularly pleasing to see that the Government, a Labor Government, has agreed to allow the entry of foreign banks to Australia with relatively flexible equity arrangements. Initially it appeared that the Government might take a contrary view and discriminate against foreign banking interests simply on the grounds that they were foreign.

The decision to allow foreign banks into Australia, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition pointed out, follows not only the lead of the Fraser Government but also the very excellent report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. That report was historic and led to at least the first stages of the revolutionising of the Australian financial system. As I said earlier, it is very pleasing to see that, instead of following the recommendations of the Martin report, the Government has opted for the broader thrust of the Campbell report. Of course, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition pointed out, it is extremely surprising that a Labor Government should have made these decisions when we recall the position it took when in opposition, a position not only of total opposition in those days to the recommendations of the Campbell report but also of total antagonism to the entry of foreign banks.

I recall, for example, that in February 1983 the present Treasurer (Mr Keating), when he was persuading his own Party to oppose foreign bank entry, said that foreign bank entry would 'link Australia to the general instability of the international banking system'; it would 'lessen the federal government's control over domestic monetary policy'. He did not point out that that would be a good thing but suggested that it would not be a good thing. He went on to say that it would 'disadvantage large sections of the Australian community' and that it would 'bring a loss of national autonomy over interest rates, the money supply and the exchange rate, which would all become more unstable, and we have fairly decent controls over the money supply and the exchange rate at present'. It is quite extraordinary that the Labor Party has reversed its position on this important issue. Coming back to the comments I made about the road to Damascus, it is reminiscent of the miracle of turning water into wine. The water of the Labor Party's policies in opposition has, at least in this respect, become a rather rich and wholesome wine.

The consequences of the decision of the Government will be extremely beneficial, as other speakers in this debate have pointed out. In the first place, the decision will have the effect of improving the services provided by the big four Australian banks which have for so long dominated our banking system. In order to demonstrate that, I quote from the Westpac Banking Corporation Review of March 1985, which states:

. . . the existing banks have done much to prepare themselves for the new competition. For instance, some of the banks have redesigned their branch networks in order to handle the business of commercial and personal customers more efficiently.

Banks have also moved to form closer links with their corporate customers by introducing sophisticated cash management systems and appointing ''relationship managers'' to look after the total financial relationship with these customers.
The balance of these considerations suggests that, while existing banks will relinquish some business to the new banks, the loss may not be as great as some would expect.

It is interesting to note that a domestic bank such as Westpac has given general support to the thrust of what the Government and the Treasurer have been about in this legislation. More generally, I do not think there is any doubt that by introducing the 16 new banks and liberalising the banking system in general-we should not forget that additional banking licences are being granted to new Australian banks-this competition will lead to a much more innovative banking sector.

In Australia, because of the rigid regulation of our banking sector, we have had a fairly unimaginative banking system, and that has disadvantaged to a considerable extent our economy and our financial system. Elsewhere, where there has been deregulation and a free flow of money in banks, there has been a much more innovative system and more services have been developed. There is no doubt that in the past the banking systems in both the United Kingdom and the United States have been much more innovative than the banks in Australia. Recently, with the threat of foreign banks arriving in Australia, the Australian banks have become considerably more innovative.

It is also encouraging to see that the new foreign banks will bring with them considerable capital which will in some respects flow through into our economy. The figure the Treasurer quoted in his statement of 27 February was that these banks would bring with them capital of about $1.5 billion.

At a time of very high unemployment we should never forget the employment impact of any measure the Government may introduce. In this case the Government estimates that the 16 new banks will create approximately 8,000 jobs. That is extremely encouraging.

As a South Australian- I crave the indulgence of the House to be a little parochial-I say that there are specific advantages for my State, which until now has had a very limited involvement in both the domestic financial system and the global financial system as a whole. As a result of this decision the Standard Chartered Bank will be established in Adelaide. That will help to drag Adelaide from being a parochial money market into the mainstream of the international financial system. That is obviously a very good thing, particularly, at a time when the Federal Government in so many other respects is both ignoring South Australia and taking decisions which are contrary to the best interests of my State. For example, none of us will forget the decisions it has taken which have, in effect, closed down both the Honeymoon and Beverley uranium mines.

The other beneficial impact of the decision to allow in the foreign banks is the element of reciprocity. I congratulate the Treasurer and the Government on not only granting the licences but also negotiating with countries from which the new banks will come to our shores to allow Australian banks to establish and operate under similar circumstances in those countries. I refer again to the Westpac Banking Corporation Review of March 1985, which makes this very point:
. . . the entry of foreign banks will enable existing Australian banks to strengthen their operations in the major regional financial centres of Hong Kong and Singapore and to open branches in Japan.

Of course, these banks will also be able to develop their activities in the United States, where their activities have been somewhat restricted in the past. They will also be able to develop their activities in the United Kingdom, where up until now they have had much greater liberty.

The end result of this decision is that in many ways it will help drag Australia into the mainstream of the international financial community. By doing that it will make a genuine contribution to economic growth. It will provide greater services to Australian industry and greater access to capital for Australian industry-things that are very badly needed in our country. It will also introduce a greater degree of competitiveness, not just in the financial sector itself but also for Australian industry, because it will provide more efficient services and possibly money at lower rates. The upshot of that will be that industry will be able to invest more cheaply and efficiently than has been the case.

This decision will give Australia the opportunity to take steps towards becoming a more important financial centre for the Asia-Pacific region. There are enormous opportunities at the moment for Australia to develop as a financial centre for our region. In the first place, there is the uncertainty about the future of Hong Kong after 1997. A large amount of capital has flowed out of Hong Kong in recent years and little of it has come to Australia. Most of the capital has gone to countries with more deregulated financial systems and more open immigration policies. There are still great opportunities for our country to take some of the business away from Hong Kong, which has been until now such an important regional financial centre.

Secondly, Australia is conveniently placed as a time zone. Honourable members will appreciate that time zones are very important in international financial markets. Australia is unique in the time zone factor and we should be able to take advantage of that. With a highly regulated system, we obviously have not taken advantage of that fact.

Thirdly, even though this country has a Labor Government, it has a great deal of political stability. In terms of attracting funds to our country and developing Australia as an international financial centre, political stability is a major factor. It is the threat of instability that is driving some money away from Hong Kong, and I hope that in the future we will be able to attract that money, partly because of our political stability.

Other decisions the Government has made, in addition to the decision on new banks, will assist in developing our country as a financial centre. The decisions to float the dollar, to free up exchange controls and to grant foreign exchange licences are all factors which will be important. Of course, those decisions go only some of the way. The trouble with this Government is that it goes only part of the way down the road to Damascus and then it wanders off into the bushes with its friends from the special interest groups.

As far as the international financial community is concerned, one decision that I regret the Government has not taken is the decision to pursue recommendations to establish off-shore banking units in our country. The Whitlam report and the Hamley report which were produced respectively by the New South Wales and Victorian governments pointed to the tremendous advantages that would be available from off-shore banking units in our country. The Whitlam report has pointed out that in the Asia-Pacific area the Asia dollar market has grown from about $400m in 1970 to $100 billion in 1983. We could get more of that action and a larger share of that market if we were to move towards the establishment of off-shore banking units in our country, as well as doing these other things which I note the Government has already done.

The Whitlam report estimates that, in terms of expenditure, off-shore banking units would outlay in the region of $300m-that would clearly be to the advantage of our economy-and that, in terms of tax receipts, they would provide the Government with about $4m, a fairly small amount. The Whitlam report also estimates that off-shore banking units in this country would create between 2,800 and 3,500 jobs. Clearly, there are very important direct benefits to be gained from moving towards off-shore banking units, but there is also the indirect benefit of contributing to Australia being an important international financial market in the world, instead of the highly protected and virtually irrelevant market that its has been in years gone by.

As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition pointed out, it is a shame that this whole process of deregulation has not been followed through in a number of other areas where it should have been. For example, we have seen the Government recently move to free up small business and personal finance. I welcome the decision that the Government has made in that respect. That decision is in line with coalition policy which was put forward at the last election. However, it is regrettable that the Government has not taken the opportunity also to deregulate housing interest rates. For the past 18 months the Government has had a golden opportunity to remove housing interest rate controls simply because those housing interest rates have been below the administered ceilings. As interest rate pressures rise, as they have been in recent weeks, the market rates approach the administered ceilings and, clearly, once the market pressures move-or tend to create forces which should move-those rates above the administered ceilings, the decision to deregulate becomes politically all the more difficult. It is a shame that the Government has not had the courage to follow through logically its decision to deregulate small business and personal finance and go ahead and deregulate housing finance as well. That regulation is only holding back funds that might otherwise go to people who want them. That is indeed disappointing.

Finally, the decision to float the Australian dollar, which has been an important contribution to bringing Australia into the international financial markets, has had its effects somewhat diminished by the fact that, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition pointed out, the Government has been so reluctant to carry its decisions logically through to the labour market and take steps to deregulate that market. The reason that it will not deregulate the labour market is not because it does not think that that is intellectually the right thing to do, but because of its passionate fear of special interest groups and, above all, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The devaluation of the Australian dollar has added between 2 and 3 per cent to the consumer price index, according to a couple of the major business groups in this country. That assumes that the Australian dollar remains at its present rate. The effect of that devaluation and its contribution to the CPI will, because of our wage fixing system, lead to an additional $4 billion wages bill for employers in Australia, both public and private sector.

The Government has refused to discount wages for the effect of devaluation. The same will apply in the case of taxation reform. If the Government follows the indicative proposals put forward by the Treasurer to the ACTU, we will find that the 12 per cent consumption tax will add 5 to 6 per cent to inflation and without wage discounting we will end up with a $9 billion wages bill on top of the $4 billion that we already have as a result of devaluation. I look forward to the Government's total policy being more consistent and coherent than it has been in the past. I hope the Government can understand the interconnection between policies and the need for intellectual consistency in all fields of policy, not just in financial markets. It is no wonder that those international financial markets have reacted so badly against Australia, which has led to the enormous devaluation of the dollar, when there are so many rigidities that the Government has built into the economic structure which are undermining our competitiveness and our scope for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate has largely taken the form of a discussion of the merits or otherwise of deregulation in economic policies and there has been talk about the virtue of deregulation in the financial system. The Opposition has said that to be intellectually consistent that should be followed through by deregulation of the labour market. I think that is a non-sequitur but I do not propose to go into that at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out in his second reading speech on the Banks (Shareholdings) Amendment Bill, this legislation facilitates the admission of the 16 new banks which are to be admitted pursuant to the statement made on 27 February. It makes a number of amendments to the Banks (Shareholdings) Act. It increases from 10 to 15 per cent the maximum holding by an individual or an association of individuals and it also specifies the grounds on which an exemption to that limit can be granted. It states that if the Governor-General is satisfied that to grant an exemption is in the national interests such an exemption can be granted. The legislation is linked in to the deregulation of the banking system which has taken place. As a result of these new entries into the banking system, we hope to see an improved competitive environment in the Australian financial system, the creation of new jobs, and the creation of more innovative banking services and, flowing from that, an increase in economic growth. Hopefully, those are the benefits that will flow from this decision.

Furthermore, as the Treasurer pointed out in his second reading speech, if exemptions are to be granted the bank will have to have an extensive record of undoubted financial strength and stability and clearly have the financial resources to maintain the bank's viability in the longer term, and give an unqualified commitment to the prudent development of the bank. Presumably, if these requirements are met, we will see, hopefully, some improvement in the functioning of the Australian financial system.

I want to sound a couple of cautionary notes. In doing so, I refer in the first instance to the recommendations in the report of the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System. The point has already been made that Martin, who was given the task of interpreting the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial system in the light of the Government's social and economic objectives, proposed that the number of new entrants should be limited to four to six and that there should be a maximum foreign equity limit of 50 per cent. Obviously the Government has decided not to follow that recommendation. I also refer back to the Campbell Committee report which, while it favoured a very liberal approach to new bank entries, emphasised one restriction and that was the need to limit in the first instance the numbers of new entrants. It cited a number of grounds for that, including:

It could lead to a period of over-aggressive competition which may have the effect of discouraging potential domestic entrants; there may be some danger of a socially unacceptable loss of resident ownership and control.

It also talked about the potential dangers involved in excessive fragmentation of the financial system and that leading to a loss of scale economies and consequently increased costs within the system. The Campbell Committee report, which was obviously extremely deregulatory in its broad thrust, nonetheless sounded a number of cautions about too large a number of new entrants in the first instance. We really have to wait and see whether the fears expressed by Campbell and Martin will be operative in the relation to the permits that have been granted to the 16 new entrants. It is by no means obvious that 16 would be an excessive number, and I am sure that the Treasurer has made a careful evaluation of that, taking into account a variety of considerations such as possible market specialisation, reciprocity arrangements, the need to get an adequate geographical spread of new entrants and so on. Bearing those factors in mind, it is to be hoped that we will not see the manifestation of the sort of problem that Martin and Campbell thought may have arisen in the event of too large a number of new entrants being allowed into the country in the first instance.

The other facet I wish to talk about relates to the problems of exercising control over multinational banks. I do not believe that one has to be a believer in multinational demonology to acknowledge that there are some potentially significant problems. In pursuance of that point, I refer to a series of hearings held by a committee of the Unites States Congress. I refer to the Sub-committee on Oversight and Investigations of the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives. Between 13 September and 17 September 1972 that sub-committee held a number of hearings on Citibank. The evidence that was presented to that inquiry makes for some sobering reading. A number of distinguished experts in the financial system gave evidence. What are most significant are the sorts of inferences that were drawn from the evidence that was presented. These things need to be taken careful account of when the Government faces the task of actually administering the financial system after the new entries have taken place. I will quote from the evidence of Richard S. Dale of the Rockefeller Foundation, who was also an international relations fellow at the Brookings Institution. Referring to Citibank's activities and a number of its malpractices, he stated:

The evidence before you shows that Citibank has used its multinational banking network, including off-shore operations in Nassau, Monaco, the Channel Islands, and Panama, to engage in what one of its officers has described as 'rinky-dink deals' designed explicitly to circumvent the following kinds of bank regulations:

First, monetary regulations in the form of minimum reserve requirements; second, exchange controls designed to limit capital outflows and capital inflows; third, tax laws applicable both to the bank itself and to its clients, and fourth, prudential controls designed to safeguard depositors and the banking system as a whole.

Included under this last heading are prudential limits on overnight foreign exchange positions, minimum capital adequacy and liquidity requirements, and official surveillance of maturity mismatching or 'gapping'.

At the outset, I would like to stress that the present framework for regulating and supervising international banking invites circumvention of the kind practised by Citibank. The ease with which deals can be booked to any part of the globe that happens to be convenient has in recent years encouraged a mushroom growth of off-shore financial centres.

I emphasise in this context that in discussing these problems we are talking not just about branches of Citibank but also about fully-owned subsidiaries. I could give a number of other quotations which would basically reinforce that point, but time does not permit that. I will quote from a working paper prepared for that sub-committee, which drew a number of conclusions about this situation. Under the heading 'Some Wider Implications of Citicorp's Evasive Strategies' the final paragraph states:

Perhaps these problems are inevitable given that regulation and disclosure in all countries tends to focus exclusively on activities in the national market. And, given the capacity for evasion inherent in off-shore operations as revealed in the Citicorp records, the narrowness of this focus and the differences in regulatory procedures that result enhance the motivations and opportunities for devising evasive strategies. Thus it could be argued that, as off-shore operations have proliferated in the 1970s, effectiveness in achieving government regulatory objectives has diminished. Reconstituting a regulatory environment that ensures that current objectives relating to the safety of depositors and investors and effective monetary control can be set will require considerably more knowledge than is currently available about the off-shore operations of multinational banks.

I conclude by making the observation that in a deregulated environment a number of significant problems are quite likely. Some will arise from the specific nature of multinational banks. In an environment where, for example, we have seen the removal of most exchange controls those sorts of matters will clearly require very close attention by government. I am sure that that attention will by given and appropriate sorts of prudential and regulatory requirements will be developed to fit into the new environment in the financial system resulting from large scale entry of foreign banks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -in reply-First of all, I thank the honourable members who participated in the debate on this very important measure and I am also grateful for those kind expressions which have come from the Opposition as well as honourable members on the Government side in respect of the real portent of this legislation which is to allow flexibility in terms of shareholding in Australian banks under the Banking Act, to permit competition in the Australian banks under the Banking Act, to permit competition in the Australian banking sector and to provide for the entry of banks owned abroad to operate and to be licensed as trading banks. These banks are to be licensed in such a way, as a number of honourable members have observed, that they will be flexible in terms of their equity so that many of them will be 100 per cent owned by their parent banks and, with those which are partly owned, they can provide effective and early competition in the Australian banking system. This has been the Government's objective in moving down this path.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that in the area of deregulation of the banking system the Government has in fact embarked upon a whole raft of deregulatory changes, the extent of which is almost unprecedented in the rest of the world and not just in this country. I will repeat, for the moment, some of those changes. Firstly, there was the floating of the Australian dollar which, in terms of deregulation, is the most fundamental of all the Government's decisions and, secondly there was the abolition of exchange controls. Other changes included the abolition, for trading banks, of deposit maturities for deposits of under 14 days. That change was made to allow trading banks to compete again with other non-bank financial institutions in the short end of the money market. The savings banks were deregulated so that they could accept from corporations deposits in excess of $100,000 and they could issue cheques when formerly they could not. The issuing of foreign exchange dealing rights to non-bank financial institutions, which formerly was the preserve of trading banks alone, was another change. I refer also to the abolition of the 30/20 rule in respect of superannuation funds. That is the requirement that they hold a certain proportion of assets in government securities. Other changes included the abolition of the control on the overdraft rate for advances under $100,000 and the reconstruction of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. It is now a tax paying institution but, importantly, the Government subscribed the equivalent of $150m of capital to its capital base-its first major capital subscription-to give that bank a future and to allow it to compete on the same kind of prudential ratios with the other privately owned trading banks in Australia. Macquarie Bank Ltd has been admitted to the stock of trading banks in this country and the NSW Permanent Building Society has been licensed as a savings bank. I have named most of the major changes, but there are other associated changes. These constitute an enormous raft of changes and they have certainly come about by virtue of a very committed view held within the Government on the need to free up the arteries of the Australian financial system to make it and, therefore, the economy more dynamic.

I certainly applaud the role of all those people associated with the course of deregulation in this country. I refer particularly to the late Sir Keith Campbell, whom I admired very much, and also to my colleague the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who also played a very important role in that process. I might add for the record, nevertheless, seeing that he took my name in vain earlier in the debate, that as far as my view is concerned he may recall the night I became shadow Treasurer was the night he announced that his Government was prepared to license foreign banks. I did the only thing that I could do at that time and that was to propagate the current prevailing view of the Australian Labor Party which, I might add, was not my own view. In fact, I will go so far as to say that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I argued in the shadow executive of the time, when the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System was presented, that we should allow the entry of foreign banks into Australia.

I say even further that at a meeting of the Committee for Economic Development of Australia I had an exchange with Mr Hamley of the National Australia Bank before even Professor Rose proposed the Campbell Committee to the former Government. I argued the need for more competition in the Australian banking sector. In fact at that time Mr Hamley was quite put out by my attack upon the existing banking structure, which I am sure he thought was unwarranted. Nevertheless, I was keen to see changes take place in the Australian banking system. I applauded the development of the Campbell Committee, the role played in that by Professor Rose and by other members of the Committee and of course the staff work which was undertaken by Mr Argy of the Treasury. It has been the blueprint document for financial deregulation. But, of course, it is much easier to write blueprints than it is to introduce the changes. That is the most important point to be drawn from this.

Whilst I do not for a moment diminish the role of the former Treasurer in this, I observe that the great changes in deregulation have really occurred under this Government. Of course, the former Treasurer did announce that he would invite applications from 10 foreign banks. But it was one thing to invite applications and another to run the gauntlet of the National Party of Australia and his Government. One could never have been sure of what would have emerged at the end. What has emerged here is a definite 16 banks-major world banks-a large proportion of which are 100 per cent foreign owned.

Deregulation of the exchange rate is a policy which the former Treasurer and others were unable to get through a coalition government. The coalition Government did not follow through its own view about deregulation. In fact, it never really had a view about anything of substance in economic policy, including the financial markets. It is all very well now for the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the honourable member for Bennelong to try to rationalise away a coalition view. There was no coherent coalition view on financial deregulation. That is why the exchange rate was never floated. In fact, it was very interesting to read the other day the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, admitting that his Government had overvalued the exchange rate as a crude anti-inflation device-obviously because under his Government anti-inflation monetary and wages policies did not exist. That Government's policies were a failure and it relied upon that particular device. Mr Fraser was quite happy to admit that the dollar was overvalued. In fact, he considered it a virtuous statement, saying: 'I told you so; you should not have floated the dollar'. I submit that that was the significant view at the time and the reason why there was never any coherence in coalition strategy in respect of financial deregulation.

The honourable member for Mayo made some remarks about the Government being inconsistent and not following its policies through, and how the business community reacts to things. Let me say that he was drawing upon what businessmen think. Without sounding too disparaging of him, I do not think that undercover Libs working in the secretariats of business organisations are businessmen; they are not the businessmen to whom I respond; a decent entrepreneur would have them for breakfast. Lest he think he comes into this Parliament receiving any respect or awe from me for him as a businessman, I just say to him that I am glad he has finally flushed himself out into the Liberal Party instead of masquerading as a business commentator for the Australian Chamber of Commerce, as he did during the first couple of years of this Government

TALK.START.PARA: —I supported you on these issues.

—I know he supports this measure but he also, in a mealy-mouthed way, attacked the way in which it was undertaken. Let me make a couple of points about financial deregulation in respect of wages. It is a nonsense to argue that one can equate in some simple way financial deregulation with deregulation of the labour market. The point is that the former Government tried it and failed. I would not mind if it at least learned something of the lessons of its history. It tried an approach of not having an incomes policy; the wage explosion of 1979-80 was the express result of its failure in that policy. The reason why one cannot make the simple analogy about deregulation of the labour market is that our labour market is not organised on an industry or enterprise basis. For a start, union organisation in this country is very high; it is over 60 per cent. It is organised on the craft union structure; it transcends industries. Anybody who thinks he can get flexibility between industries in this kind of environment simply by saying 'We are going to deregulate' or 'We are going to walk away from the accord' is very foolish. The likelihood is that any increases which go to what may be termed the high points of the economy would, on the basis of the current institutional arrangements in our labour market, flow right through the economy, as we have seen over and over again. That is why this Government has chosen a different policy in respect of the labour market from that chosen by the coalition Government. That is why we have succeeded in bringing down inflation. That is why we now have an exchange rate which is reflecting our lack of competitiveness following a period of high inflation and the overvaluation of the exchange rate by the former Government. That is why I put to Opposition members that it is just nonsense to try to make the simple analogy between labour market deregulation and deregulation of the financial system. Of course, the other view is that, if one deregulates the financial system, there is some problem about the lack of so-called deregulation of the labour market. To put the argument in reverse, if one does not deregulate the labour market, there should be a constipated financial market. That makes no sense.
—Oh!

—I was not ascribing that policy to the honourable member for Mayo, but it is a view which has been put about. My view is that one takes the best from the financial market, makes it as free and responsive as possible and, in the institutional constraints of the Australian labour market, one responds with the most appropriate policy. The most appropriate policy approach in which my Party believes is that of the prices and incomes accord, which has already delivered a diminishing rate of inflation, high growth and high employment growth in a short time.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding that indiscretion on the Opposition's part, I do nevertheless appreciate its support of the measure that the Government has taken. I appreciate the forthright comments of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the generous comments which he has made from time to time about the Government's changes. I also appreciate the generous comments the honourable member for Mayo made about the Government's policy in this direction. I believe that some structural changes in this country go beyond the particular views or nuances of a party and that, when big changes are afoot, those which deserve broad support should get it. That has been the case. From the Government's point of view, we certainly welcome the Opposition's support for this measure.

I suppose one can reach the point where the deregulatory agenda is simply expelled or expunged. But there is still more to be done and I suppose, in a sense, governments will need to continue to be vigilant in keeping markets as free and open as is possible. That is something to which I certainly subscribe. I use this opportunity to say to honourable members opposite and to the former Prime Minister that this Government has been entirely pleased with the floating of the Australian dollar. If we could have our time over again, we would do nothing other than what we have done with the exchange rate. It is a good long-standing change in policy for this country.

I conclude by saying that the passage of the Banks (Shareholdings) Amendment Bill will provide for that flexibility in the ownership structure of banks outside the normal constraints of the Australian Bank (Shareholdings) Act, which formerly allowed an interest of only 10 per cent. Now, in the normal case, it will be 15 per cent. The exemption whereby the Treasurer of the day can recommend to the Governor-General-in-Council that the Governor-General exercise his discretion under the Act to permit a shareholding in excess of 15 per cent will mean that banks will be allowed to operate in this country with an equity structure very much different from that with which they have operated in the past. We now have the cream of the world's banks about to enter the Australian financial system. Like the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Mayo, I sincerely believe that Australia has the opportunity of becoming an important international financial centre. We have a politically stable country. It is an English-speaking country. It is in the right time zone to play a useful role in the world's capital markets. Therefore, the changes which we have seen in the advent of these major international institutions can, over time, build Australia into an important financial centre. All countries sell what they have to sell. What Australia has to sell is its stability, its good name and the sensible management of its economic and national affairs. That is an environment that is very conducive to major institutions establishing themselves here, looking at the Asia-Pacific area.

With that in mind, the Government is still looking at the question of off-shore banking units. If, on balance, it decides that the benefits of accommodating such institutions are not outweighed by the costs-in other words, that we are not forgoing too much in terms of the revenue which now comes by way of, for instance, withholding tax and other such matters-and that we would be advantaged in moving to trading in currencies other than our own in off-shore banking units, then we would have yet another dimension to the prospect of Australia as an international financial centre.

I again thank honourable members on both sides for their contribution. This is an historic piece of legislation. These are historic changes, and it is good that they are accompanied by unanimity in the Parliament. The Government is very grateful for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this place there would be as many views about the preferable hours and days of sitting as there are members, but there is little doubt that the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Young) is sensible in the circumstances of the program that he has outlined.
