It is very necessary that in any extension of sitting hours there is an acceptance that the 11 o'clock closure is something that most honourable members regard as sacrosanct. It is important that the Government does not legislate by exhaustion. I trust that the 11 o'clock closure can be maintained with the reasonable provision of the 10.15 p.m. to 11 p.m. adjournment debate, which enables the private member to make an individual contribution on matters which might be of major importance to him but which otherwise he would not reasonably be able to canvass within the normal procedures of the business of the House.

I believe that the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings Committee also should consider the adjournment debate. There have been some general comments about some possible change to our sessional orders to permit the broadcasting of excerpts of parliamentary proceedings. That is a procedure which the Opposition endorses, although we suggest that it be on a trial basis to give us an opportunity to ensure that there is a balance between the sides of the House. I suggest that that Committee might also consider the broadcasting of the adjournment debate. Many honourable members speak during the adjournment debate on matters that are of real significance to them. It is a pity that, just because it is private members' business, it is excluded from the broadcast proceedings. If there are troubles with parliamentary privilege-I do not believe that there are-they can be examined separately. But there would be an advantage for everyone in this place if the adjournment debate were broadcast. If it is the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings Committee rather than the Procedure Committee that is examining those matters, this might be another matter that it could bring up and hopefully change. Of course, we would not expect this in the next three weeks of sitting, but it is something that we might expect to come in by sessional order at the commencement of the Budget sittings.

It is also important that we realise that, after these next three weeks, the Government intends to get up and run. While we can understand that its present practices justify its running, the Australian public is a little concerned that the Government will be removed from public scrutiny throughout that long period from the end of these May sittings until the presentation of the Budget late in August. I know that it has been a practice of governments not to sit any longer than necessary for the introduction and passage of their legislation, but I am one of those who believe that it is important that the Parliament sit longer than it now does. By 'longer', I do not mean later at night; I mean over a greater period of the year than is now the case.

If we wish to establish ourselves as the major parliament in Australia and if we want to try to make sure that people regard this Parliament as having relevance to issues that are of consequence in the running of the nation, the one way of meeting that responsibility is to be here. We do not do it by absenting ourselves for months on end. I know that there are reasons for having a break in the middle of the year, but I believe that it would be far more satisfactory if we had a sitting period that ran until at least towards the end of June. That would still give the Government an opportunity to consider its Budget preparation and then to introduce the Budget after a period of about a month and a half during which the Parliament would not be sitting.

There is reason for us to re-examine the period of the year during which the Parliament sits. I would certainly support an extension and I believe that many other members of the Opposition think it is necessary. I might add that I put that point of view forward when we were in government and I was sitting in the chair that the Minister now occupies. That point of view did not always receive unanimous support from the members of the Government of which I was a part, but I believe that it is necessary. It is something that I put to all honourable members of this place as being a necessary consequence of what I see as the added complexity of government and, I believe, the increased responsibility of this place. Obviously a number of questions arise regarding particular issues that could emerge during the winter recess. We are not debating an adjournment motion at this moment but I say to the Leader of the House that we in the Parliament would expect the Government to recall the House if matters such as that should arise.

One matter that particularly concerns us is the fact that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) seems to have gone off in this instance on what I would suggest is little more than a jaunt. He has done so in circumstances in which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was called on today to respond to a question about the disarmament talks that are being undertaken with representatives of the Soviet Union and the United States of America. That is a major issue of concern to this Parliament and to the people of Australia. This Government cannot meaningfully address the question of disarmament if its Foreign Minister absents himself for the whole of the balance of the sittings of the Federal Parliament. For that reason alone we are most concerned that the Parliament is to rise in three weeks. I see justification not only in the Parliament sitting on those Wednesday evenings but also in added opportunities being provided for us all to hear the Foreign Minister make a statement in this place about the disarmament talks which he has pursued. Let us have a debate to see whether there is any sincerity in the Government's approach to this very vital and critical issue which affects us all. With that little bit of a background, the Opposition will support the measure proposed by the Leader of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks made by the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), and to support reluctantly the motion before the House. I will not detain the House at any great length in so doing but I would like to point out for the record that this is the Parliament's twenty-first day of sitting since the election on 1 December last year. We have had 21 days of sitting out of the 158 days which have elapsed since that time. I guess that, on face value, the public at large would say that we have been sitting for three weeks, in their semblance of 21 days, when in fact five months have passed and the House should have been sitting a whole lot more, given all the issues that abound and all the problems which are faced by the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise fully that there are severe scheduling problems with Cabinet and ministerial commitments and with the structure of the sitting of Parliament. This House is locked into a program of sitting four days back to back, which has some merit and some non-merit if I might put it that way, and it is a matter which is before the Standing Committee on Procedure at the moment. But I put it to the House and perhaps to the nation that 21 days of sitting out of 158 days or five months is totally inadequate in terms of the very real problems that are facing so many in the nation. I refer, for example, to the drought which is rapidly re-establishing itself over so much of eastern Australia-in the western parts of the electorate of Farrer, in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), south of the Murray River and in the electorate of Maranoa. Many other electorates are rapidly having pasture protection board areas re-declared drought areas with the attendant problems associated with that. If honourable members want to be brought right up to date, I refer more particularly to the issue of the Army base. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) has lost a battle for his electorate and Singleton is to lose the Army base. It is to be shifted to the Orange-Bathurst area, which will have great and important ramifications. Notwithstanding the three extra Wednesday nights of sitting conferred by this motion, I doubt that we will have time, even allowing for those three extra Wednesday nights, to discuss issues of that nature.

Some of the legislation which will be rushed through the Parliament during the next three weeks concerns such vital areas as the land transport program-a massive piece of legislation which we have not yet seen copies of-which deserves detailed examination if local government is to be protected, if our road construction authorities at the State level are to be protected and if this country is to get value out of the dollars expended on local, State and Federal road programs. In the passage of the next three weeks that legislation will suddenly enter the statute book and lay down at a Federal level a program of roads construction in this nation, for better or worse, for the next five years.

There is a huge package of rural legislation on the Notice Paper. Many troubled areas are deserving of very detailed consideration, including the restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board, alterations to the dried fruits industry, the dairy industry situation, the sugar industry and many other areas which are in dire straits and which should be the subject of proper discussion. However, I realise that this motion deals specifically with extending the sittings for the next three Wednesday nights. Frankly, I am delighted that we will not have to go to a certain movie which was scheduled to be shown tomorrow night subject to the acceptance of some honourable members. I am happy to serve my electorate in this House as often as it sits.

I make the point that 21 sitting days out of five months since the election on 1 December is inadequate. At the end of the autumn session we will have totalled 32 days of sitting in a six-month period, which I believe is absolutely inadequate. I support strongly the comments of the right honourable member for New England and Leader of the National Party that we in this nation must steadily mature in terms of the sittings of our Parliament and move towards a concept of sittings throughout the year with a reasonable continuity of legislation and not this log-jam rush at the end of the session.

Finally, I take this opportunity to put it to the House that if we are to have these four-day back-to-back sittings, which are the delight of certain Western Australians-other Western Australians assure me that they hate them because they like to get home even on the short weekends and there is no real saving for the taxpayer in the four-day back-to-back sittings-I have submitted to the Procedure Committee and I commend to the House that there is a better way to do it. Rather than having the four-day sittings we should permanently set in concrete that the sittings be from Monday lunchtime through to Thursday evening. That would at least allow Ministers and others to schedule their Fridays well ahead. At the moment we have a situation in which, even allowing for the courtesy of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) in circulating the Budget sitting dates-I very much appreciate that action-we still have that area of doubt about when and where Ministers and others can schedule Fridays for commitments in their electorates and elsewhere. It becomes a real problem.

If we are to have four-day sittings into the next year and beyond, let them be looked at on the basis of always being from a Monday lunchtime through to a Thursday evening, which is what will apply for the next two weeks in any case. The precedent is there and it is followed to some extent now. At least then we would know that our Fridays were clear for scheduling away from the Parliament. But, of course, some of us would prefer the other system of a three-day, three-week approach.

Next Tuesday night this nation is to be presented with an economic mini-Budget of $1 billion in cutbacks. We were assured at Question Time this afternoon that this is fair dinkum, that it will involve $1 billion and perhaps a great deal more than $1 billion. I just make the point that we need time to consider carefully the statement that is to be made next Tuesday night. We need time and it is our duty to spend time considering on the floor of this House of Representatives and in the other place the issues of real concern in the community at large. We will get that time only if the sittings of this Parliament are extended, if there are more days of sitting and a more proper scheduling of the proceedings of this House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Rural Industries Research Bill 1985 concurrently with the Rural Industries Research (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1985, the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1985, the Tobacco Charge (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1985, the Tobacco Charge (No. 3) Amendment Bill 1985, the Poultry Industry Levy Amendment Bill 1985 and the Poultry Industry Assistance Amendment Bill 1985. If there is no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Opposition will move, after the suspension of the sitting for dinner, the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Rural Industries Research Bill to highlight the inadequate effort of the Hawke Labor Government to liaise with the primary industries over its legislative program:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Minister for Primary Industry has failed to adequately consult with a number of rural industries about certain aspects of this legislation, and calls upon him to consult with those industries about their concerns as a matter of urgency'.

The legislation is drafted to amalgamate the existing rural industry research legislation and provide one Act for the administration of rural industry research funds. It revamps the Commonwealth special research grants scheme and gives a compact basis for future funding needs. There is much sense in attempting to consolidate most of the 14 trust accounts covering the barley, chicken meat, cotton, dried fruits, dairy, fish, honey, oil seeds, pigs, poultry, tobacco, wheat, wine and wool industries. In foreshadowing this amendment, I draw attention to an anomalous situation affecting the Australian pork producers and the serious reservations held by the poultry, dairy, honey and tobacco industries.

The Australian Pork Producers Federation is opposed to the inflexible way in which the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has constructed the core committee of the Research Councils Selection Committee to appoint people to the industry research councils. Although concern has been widely expressed over the lack of a producer majority on the Selection Committee, the Bill provides for the establishment of a Research Councils Selection Committee to select additional members with special qualifications and expertise for the research councils. The Selection Committee will comprise a core committee and industry representation. The core committee will comprise an independent chairperson to be appointed by the Minister, one nominee from the National Farmers Federation, one nominee from the Australian Agricultural Council and one member with knowledge and expertise in scientific matters, research and development and/or marketing to be appointed by the Minister. The specific industry concerned shall have up to three industry representatives, the actual number to be determined by the Minister after consultation with relevant industry organisations.

I do hope the Minister on this occasion, to accord with the intention that is expressed in the legislation, actually consults the organisations in a manner in which he does not seem to have consulted a number of organisations that have brought their concerns and worries to me as the shadow Minister. The Minister will make the appointments after they have been nominated by the relevant industry organisations. The Pork Producers Federation, in discussion with the Minister, sought changes in this legislation to the structure of the Selection Committee core committee. The Federation quite rightly points out that it is not an affiliated member of the National Farmers Federation; Therefore the representative from the NFF on the core committee should be replaced by a member of the Australian Pork Producers Federation when matters relating to the pork producers are being decided.

The Federation submitted a reasonable case to the Minister, who has reacted in a negative and unco-operative way. Unfortunately the Minister seems unable to accept that he is capable of making a mistake. Clearly, he was not aware that the APPF was not an affiliate of the NFF. If he was aware, he is totally insensitive, if not arrogant. He has placed the pig industry in a position where it will have a minority representation of three in a committee of seven, which does not meet the spirit or the intention that the Minister purports to espouse. The Pork Producers Federation case has been treated with contempt by the Minister. I do not think it is fair to treat a non-affiliate of the NFF as though it is an affiliate.

The dairy industry also holds deep reservations about this legislation. This reservation has only recently been brought to my attention. There are a number of reasons why the industry believes it should be afforded the same treatment as the wool and the wine industries, which were allowed to continue research under the existing arrangements. Firstly, the industry has an excellent track record, with the dairy research scheme having been successfully administered by the Australian Dairy Corporation to the benefit of dairy farmers and consumers alike. Secondly, the dairy farmers' marketing arrangements are likely to change in the immediate future. It is grossly inconsistent for the Minister to justify the continuation of current wine research because an inquiry into the industry is under way, yet on the other hand to force the dairy research program to change when such a change is actively opposed by the industry. The dairy farmers are being treated as second class citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I know that the very dutiful honourable member for Gippsland, where some of the most efficient dairy farmers produce their product, knows how distressed these people are and under what difficulties they are labouring at present. Another reason for their exclusion from the Bill is the contempt with which their requests to the Minister have been treated.
—No consultation.

—There has been no consultation whatsoever with the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. This Federation outlined its concern over this Bill in a letter dated 29 March and sought to discuss the provisions with the Minister for Primary Industry. To date there has been no response to the industry's approach. Currently the cost of the administration and direction of the scheme, including the new charges made by the Department of Primary Industry for investment management and financial administration governed by clause 9 (1) (e) of the Rural Industries Research Bill, amounts to some 10 per cent of the value of the program. The complex administrative requirement of this Bill with respect to the provisions for five-year research and development plans and yearly programs, together with the selection procedure for the Research Council members, will probably double these costs. For the dairy industry at least, current procedures achieve much the same goals but at a lower cost. It is noteworthy that the Research Council will be unable to completely control efficiency and its administrative costs. At present expenditure from the research trust fund may only be approved following a recommendation from the Research Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner and our celebration of the Japanese Emperor's eighty-fifth birthday, I was talking about rural research in Australia and about the Rural Industries Research Bill which is designed to amalgamate a number of Acts under one umbrella piece of legislation in order to simplify the procedures for rural research. I had referred to the dairying industry. Of course the dairy industry has expressed some concern that there was inadequate consultation with it in respect of aspects of this legislation. It is noteworthy, Madam Deputy Speaker--
—Madam Acting Speaker, not Madam Deputy Speaker.

—I am sorry; I think so much of you that I would hate to say the wrong thing. I think you are the best of them, I must say. It is noteworthy that the Special Rural Research Council would be unable to control completely efficiency and its administrative costs. At present expenditure from the special rural research fund may be approved only following a recommendation from the Research Council. The provisions of the Rural Industries Research Bill permit expenditure under clause 9 (1) (e) without reference to the Research Council. In addition, under clause 46, the proposal to distance the Research Council from the industry through the appointment of members who have qualifications relevant to, or have expertise in, a number of fields rather than having industry representation could be very counter-productive. Amongst other things, it will threaten the close links established between the industry and the Australian Dairy Research Committee. I stress that the present arrangements have been of enormous benefit not only to the industry-I think that is very important-but also to the end users, the consumers in Australia. Unless these links are maintained there will be considerable reluctance at the farm level to contribute to dairying research. That would be a great pity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition recognises that these Bills increase the maximum contribution by the Government to industry research but is concerned that the response of the dairy industry has been ignored. The matter is of very great importance to an industry which makes a considerable financial contribution to its own research programs and which stands to benefit greatly from research efforts. At present there is an oversupply of milk of about 10 per cent and research could provide vital avenues for the disposal of this surplus of protein without the need for such drastic measures as those to be imposed under the current Government's marketing scheme. I do make that plea quite sincerely because Australia has a very serious problem in regard to its overproduction and market availability. I know that the Minister has tried to grapple with this problem in his own way, and in the Government's way, and the industry itself has also endeavoured to come up with a proposal. I hope that somewhere along the line some sensible resolution can be achieved to overcome what is a very difficult economic problem and, more importantly, a very difficult social problem.

There is a perception around that farmers are well to do and that people need not to be concerned about their situation. We now live in a cash economy. At one time, for instance when I was born on to the land, people were envious of those who owned property because they had capital assets and capital backing, but the situation has become quite reversed because we do live in a cash economy and unless a person has a well paid job or is involved in an industry with a good cash flow his economic security is not assured. I say that in all sincerity and I do hope that members of the Government recognise that great poverty is looming in the rural areas of Australia. So many young people are deciding to leave the farm; they are wanting to get away into some other area of activity, and that is sad for Australia because the time will come when we will not have enough people engaged in farming unless we go back to those vast farm acreages that used to exist in the last century. I would hate to see the movement accelerate to the extent where we have ghost towns and large corporate-type operations with all sorts of measures to try to reduce labour. I dare say that this is a trend that is taking place in many areas, but it will be a sad thing for Australia if people lose their interest in the great heritage of this vast continent, which is not well settled away from the coastline.

The Hawke Labor Government should take the initiative and consult with the industry over the changes needed to this legislation. If necessary the Government should take the initiative and defer the Bills-at least in relation to the dairying industry, which could be subject to other legislation in the budget Session. The subsequent legislation could still be operative by the same time as these Bills are to take effect, that is, from 1 January 1986. I can understand why the Minister is trying to do this. Basically I think the Minister is on the right track. He is trying to reduce the number of Acts and trying to consolidate a lot of legislation which probably should have been consolidated many years ago. I give him some credit for that but in his rush and under the burden of trying to get all that legislation together-as a former Minister I know what sorts of pressures one can be under-he should be careful that he does not at the same time ignore the people whom the legislation is likely to affect; ignore consultation and lose touch. I think that is one of the problems of government in modern society. I do not know what sorts of measures one can take to avoid it but one needs at least to be aware of it. Ultimately, a government that ignores this consultation process suffers and fails in the longer term.

The dairy industry is in a difficult position. It does not agree that the provisions of these Bills are best for the industry. However, the Government holds the purse strings because it is a dollar for dollar contribution and without the Commonwealth dollar the effort would be rather meagre. The industry, therefore, will have to try to co-operate in the best way it can. In essence, this Government has a chance to practise consensus. It would help to restore some of the credibility that the Government seems to have lost amongst farmers in recent months if the provisions that apply to dairying were taken out of this legislation and discussed with a view to introducing separate legislation in the next session. I call upon the Government to take this initiative. I do no more than that because I believe that in the final analysis it is the responsibility of the Government to take action and I do not think it is the job of the Opposition to hold up a piece of legislation of this importance. The Minister would be doing no more than he is doing for the honey industry if he were to defer the provisions of this Bill which apply to the dairy industry and then use the regulations provisions in the Bill at a later stage when a reasonable arrangement has been made with the industry.

For smaller scale industries such as the honey and poultry industries the administrative charges under the rural industry research Bills will be a heavy burden. In the case of the larger wool research effort, the Department of Primary Industry administrative charges represent about 5 per cent of the annual budget for research. In contrast, these charges swallow about 20 per cent of the poultry industry's research budget and 17 per cent of the honey industry's research funds. As I mentioned earlier, dairying faces a doubling of its administrative costs to 20 per cent. For the honey research fund the 17 per cent administrative cost amounts to $14,846. Of this, $7,824 is paid in salaries, but the on-costs are set at 84 per cent of salaries, that is, $6,527. The on-costs of 84 per cent seem extraordinarily high to me. It seems reasonable to ask the Minister to review this figure as it is quite possible his review could lead to a scaling down of the administrative costs with a resulting increase in the actual research effort. Additionally, were grant recipients to ask for on-cost provision of 84 per cent themselves, the number of projects would inevitably have to fall.

The alternative would be to raise the levy closer to the 0.5 per cent of gross value of production level, a move which would be strongly resisted by the industry. It would be a great pity if excessive cost recovery were to jeopardise the actual research work. In addition to administrative costs, while larger industries can more easily justify the costs of core committees, the burden on smaller industries is relatively high. The smaller industries also rely more heavily on specialist expertise on their committees, yet these Bills may reduce the contribution of those directly engaged in a broad range of industry activity.

The three Tobacco Charge Bills repeal the Tobacco Industry Act of 1965 but essentially continue arrangements already in place for funding tobacco research and the expenses of the Australia Tobacco Board. Levies for industry research already exceed the 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production limit set in the other Bills before the House. In February this year the levy rose from 2.5c per kilogram to 3.5c. The Government has agreed to continue to match this funding level, and this is formalised in clause 7 (3) (b) of the Rural Industries Research Bill.

The declining level of production had meant that the overall research program was in jeopardy unless additional funds could be raised. It is of concern that a further increase may be needed in two or three years, but the commitment of the Government to match these increased levy funds is not clear. It would be helpful to the industry if the Government could spell out in more detail its commitment to continued matching of these funds. I would point out that the industry is relatively small, and already contributes more than others to its research. In a declining market scenario this research becomes even more important.

In relation to the five-year plans to be introduced, the Opposition is concerned to ensure that this time span does not compromise the flexibility of research programs. Committees will need to be on guard against an attitude that projects not in the five-year plan cannot be undertaken. Our primary industries are dynamic, not static. Their needs can change quite rapidly, and it would be most unfortunate if urgent works could not be tackled in response to urgent market challenges.

Turning to poultry research, I hold a number of reservations about the changes made although I do note that the Australian Egg Marketing Council fully supports the Minister's aims and objectives for research. As I mentioned, administrative costs will take about 20 per cent of the research moneys. I think it is quite unacceptable for any research program to find that 20 per cent of its funds have been taken up by administration. It seems to me to be an extraordinary burden. The Poultry Research Advisory Committee, a non-statutory body, is one of the smaller research funds with a total budget of some $400,000. In recent years the Committee has made a commendable effort to become more cost-effective, and the industry had understood that changes to rural industry research funds as a result of the joint management review would not apply in its case. After advice from the Department seven months ago that PRAC would become statutory, the industry considered its position and in February advised the Minister that it wished to remain non-statutory. This view has been rejected, and now the industry will lose 20 per cent of its research funds in administration costs alone.

Beyond the cost problem, I know the industry is concerned about losing control over the direction of its research and about the Committee no longer being fully accountable to the industry. There is also a degree of anger among poultry producers that they have had little time to study the new system. The first details were advised to rural research funds chairmen in late December. This has left little time for industries, including the poultry producers, to discuss the new regulations and come to a common view. It is a pity the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry seem to be abandoning their much-vaunted consensus. The Minister ought to realise that he is making few friends and a lot of enemies with his approach to these industries, in regard to consultation.

An interesting aspect of this legislation is that it makes maximum provision for an increased Commonwealth funding up to a maximum-and I stress that-contribution of 0.5 per cent of the annual gross value of production for each of the industries concerned. At the present time the contribution averages out at about 0.25 per cent. This Bill therefore provides for a doubling of the Commonwealth's funding should the industries make an increased contribution. The funding will, of course, be on a dollar for dollar basis. At the present time there is no Commonwealth limit-and I stress that-on its financial contribution with the exception of poultry industry research, which currently has a limit of $150,000 per financial year.

The former Government was also mindful of the importance of research. Indeed, it treated the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation with much more generosity than does the current Government. While the Hawke Labor Government makes a maximum provision of Commonwealth funds for rural research, subject to industry contribution on a dollar for dollar basis, the same Government has diverted funds from the agricultural sector of the CSIRO to other sectors. I am sorry the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) has done this because I think he is one of the better Ministers. I think that horse in Melbourne really sorted him out the other day when it gave him a good old nudge, a kick and a side swipe. I think the horse was acting on behalf of the animals of Australia when it did that, so I hope the Minister will take note and give more serious consideration to the important problems of research in this area.

All this Bill really achieves is to place a maximum on the amount of research money the Commonwealth will extend to rural research, establish a selection committee and consolidate several pieces of legislation into one larger Bill. So let us not get carried away with the notion that the Bill will necessarily give a generous lift to Commonwealth research funds. It will not necessarily increase funds for rural research. It provides for a maximum contribution from the Commonwealth Government and maintains the dollar for dollar principle in rural research. The Bill really ensures that there will be a limit to the amount of funds the Minister will have available for rural industries research. —Madam Acting Speaker, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say from the outset that I am sure that the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), was being flippant in moving this amendment. SPEECH.PARA: The Rural Industries Research Bill 1985 puts into effect an undertaking given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last November when he announced that the Government's contribution to rural research would be increased. To complement this larger funding commitment, the Bill also provides for major organisational changes in the administration of research funding. The keynote of these changes is deregulation. As in any co-operative effort between government and industry, there has from time to time been conflict of opinion as to levels of contribution and participation. This legislation recognises the very substantial obligation of government to ensure that research continues and is adequately financed. At the same time, it recognises that producers must be given full opportunity for representation in decision-making areas where funds are allocated and projects determined.

As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said in his second reading speech, attention has been paid also to ensuring that the greatest possible returns are achieved from each dollar spent and that those who administer and undertake research are fully accountable to the providers of funds. The Government's part in this revitalisation begins with the provision for Commonwealth funding to be increased to about double its present average rate, or up to 5 per cent of the annual gross value of production of each industry, depending on the level of contribution by that industry. The Government will contribute on a dollar-for-dollar basis and will seek to encourage industry investment in research up to the maximum of 5 per cent of GVP over a five-year period. At present, the average Government research funding level in all industries receiving it is about 26 per cent of GVP. Other measures will be taken to remove any obstacles in the way of approval for any industry wishing to increase its own funding for further research beyond that covered by the 5 per cent of GVP that is subject to matching by Government.

The rural industry research councils, which will replace the former research committees in the role of administering funds, may well see the new emphasis on greater independence reflected first in the composition of their membership. This will be decided by a selection committee which will have substantial industry involvement. Each council will comprise five to nine members, including a chairperson and one Government member, both appointed by the Minister. The criteria to be adopted by the selection committee will be aimed solely at producing the best possible blend of individual expertise and experience in the relevant fields, rather than being subject to requirements of representation of selected organisations. There will be less ministerial involvement than formerly in the day to day running of the councils' research efforts, which will be determined by them in the production of annual research and development programs. Overall guidelines for these annual programs will be set in a five-year strategic research and development plan which each council will be required to produce in consultation with industry and submit for the Minister's approval.

All these adjustments reflect this Government's aim of fostering a more autonomous and decisive role by councils in the selection and attainment of research and development goals that have been endorsed by producers in consultation with the industry concerned. The Government wants to see the councils equipped to get on with the job and free to do so without being hamstrung by regulations. Accountability of research councils has been designed to include a planning and consultative mechanism that will remove any need for the Minister to approve funding of individual research projects and minor alterations to approved budgets. The chief vehicle for this accountability will continue to be the annual report which will be tabled in Parliament. This will be expected to compare performance with the stated aims of the strategic plan. The council chairperson will be responsible for presenting the report to the executive of the most relevant industry organisation and discussing performance and plans. When the report is subsequently presented to industry it will contain the comments of the executive.

The terms outlined will apply to 11 major rural industries from 1 January 1986. Others, for a variety of reasons, have not yet been included in the reorganisation. As the representative of an electorate which takes in vast areas of agricultural land, I find the decisions to greatly increase both funding to and consultation with industry very satisfying indeed.

Quite apart from this, I must say that I cannot think of a more deserving recipient of an expanded effective research effort than rural industry, for the following reasons. Rural exports generate a high proportion of export earnings-about 40 per cent by value-with a significant effect on the national economy. Rural products have a high potential for downstream processing, creating further industrial and economic benefits. There is a relatively low level of general government assistance to rural industry compared to that given the manufacturing sector, largely in the form of tariffs, which add to costs of rural producers. Australian ownership in the rural sector is high compared to that in the manufacturing and mining sectors. These reasons are basic. They have always applied. But future indications suggest that winning gains from research will be an ever more demanding task as rural production and environmental problems become ever more complex and subtle.

Research into subjects such as plant genetics and molecular biology, with the aim of producing more disease-resistant, higher yielding and drought-resistant plant varieties, and increasingly serious problems such as soil erosion, salinity and biological control of pests and weeds, will become increasingly necessary to maintain the competitiveness of Australian agriculture and its significant contribution to the national economy. The structure of the agricultural industry is the reason why it would be unlikely to be capable of producing an adequate program if left to its own resources.

Australian agriculture is an amalgam of independent businesses, comprising some 176,000 commercial holdings and nearly 80,000 holdings rated as unproductive. Individual businesses on this scale lack the resources for their own effective research programs and there is not much prospect of worthwhile returns for private investors in the field. By contrast, the potential rewards on a national level for a soundly planned, government backed research and development program constitute a very worthwhile investment. Apart from its provision for increased funding, the main changes brought about by this Bill concern bringing together separate avenues of rural research under one Act, where at present possible, and improving efficiency in the process.

Financing is at present carried out through 14 trust accounts, known as rural industry trust funds, or RITFs, administered through research committees under separate legislation. The 14 existing trust accounts cover barley, chicken meat, cotton, dried fruits, dairy, fish, honey, oilseeds, pigs, poultry, wheat, wine, wool and tobacco. Fund administration and planning will become the responsibility of the new research councils in the case of 11 major industries.

Poultry, wool and wine are currently excluded from the provisions of the Bill. Poultry research is subject to special arrangements. The wool industry for many years has been setting a good example to others with its Wool Research Trust Fund. Both the industry and the community have derived considerable benefit from the research achievements stemming from this Fund. Under the new legislation, the Australian Wool Corporation will be left free to adopt administrative arrangements, where these will be of benefit.

The grape and wine industries will be consulted on new arrangements for wine research when the current inquiry is completed and a report is issued. Fisheries research is also subject to consultations, which are now under way. The tobacco industry will be subject to a special arrangement. It is already funded for research to a higher level than the new maximum of 0.5 per cent of GVP by an agreement reached with the Government in 1984, and this will continue to apply.

Further scope for common interest is given in the Bill's provision for an annual co-ordination meeting of all chairpersons of research councils for discussion of topics of concern to all. These meetings will also include the Australian Special Rural Research Council, the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation, and the Wool Research Trust Fund. The common objective of all these organisations will be to increase commercial returns to their industries by improving production, processing, storage, transport and marketing of their respective products. They will be responsible for identifying research targets and determining priorities for funding and promotion of research and development programs to meet these objectives.

For smaller and emerging industries the present arrangements for funding will continue under the Commonwealth special research grants scheme. Government and industry currently contribute about $32m each to this scheme. The special grants scheme will be strengthened in view of its other intended role of interdisciplinary research. This could take the form of a research project that would benefit a number of rural industries, but which is not sufficiently important to any one of them for inclusion in its own program. Funds could also be made available for research undertaken in the national interest. The CSRG scheme will be given statutory status under the Bill and renamed the Australian Special Rural Research Council. It will embody the same principles as apply to the rural industry research councils and will have its funding increased.

A salient feature of the Rural Industries Research Bill is the emphasis it gives in a number of ways to getting active participation from industry, rather than the relatively passive role industry has played in research planning up to now. This will apply all the way from the early stage of selection of research council members, through to all aspects of research programming of the annual accountability and assessment process. The make-up of the Research Councils Selection Committee is a fair example of the care that has gone into giving industry its full share of influence. A core group of three on the Selection Committee, who will take part in selecting all council members, will include two people nominated by agricultural industry bodies. A second selection group of up to three members, chosen by consultation with each specific industry, will share in selection of council members for that industry.

The Rural Industries Research (Transitional Provisions and Consequent Amendments) Bill 1985 is complementary to the Rural Industries Research Bill. Its purpose is to amend or repeal existing legislation, where necessary, for the enactment of the Rural Industries Research Bill, and to provide the necessary transitional arrangements for the changeover. It will also provide for transfer of assets to the new research funds, and will minimise disruption to current research programs by maintaining present agreements until the new Bill comes into effect. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment before the House focuses on rural research. The history of Australian agriculture is the history of innovative research that has kept us competitive. It has been in fact the only tool we have had, along with industrious farmers, to provide us with some sort of shield against the inequitable trading arrangements we have had to face overseas. Nineteen eighty-eight will mark 200 years of agricultural resourcefulness. Almost 200 years ago, when the first people started tilling this land, things had changed very little from biblical days. It is a sad reflection on the unreality of this House that if I were to stand here and talk about a stripper, the first thing most people in the House would think about would be that sort of sensual act that sadly exploits womanhood. It is sobering to consider that it is only 80 years since Gregor Mendel made the first tentative steps in discovering what genetics was all about. Only in those 80 years have we understood what plant breeding is all about and only in that time have we been able to apply those same lessons to animal breeding. By applying the very techniques that he developed 80 years ago we would be able to bring into Australian agriculture those measures of drought tolerance and salt tolerance that are so desperately needed. Is this essential role of agricultural research addressed in this legislation? Sadly, no. Not only is there no mention of plant variety rights, but in addition, only last week this report came from The Country Hour. I quote from it:

A Senate Committee recommended that the Commonwealth considered the introduction of a PVR scheme but in response the Commonwealth has said it is committed to an inquiry before a PVR scheme is introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not another one.

—Well may the honourable member for Wannon cry out: 'Not another one'. Never has an agricultural initiative been so plagued with inquiries as has the role of PVR and never has there been an area of rural research as desperately needed by Australian agriculturalists. Yet all we have is another inquiry. It does not matter where we look in Australian agriculture, whether it is at the tiniest area of genetic development or the broad area of the bulk handling of our crops, there is a great opportunity for increased rural research. SPEECH.PARA: This Bill should have been designed to redress some of the shortcomings in agricultural research in Australia. I quote from a statement made by the present Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) who, as the Minister for Finance, was at a time last year fiddling in research matters. CSIRO should redirect its resources away from the agricultural sector, and generally demonstrate its ability to change direction.

. . . and in particular the wish for CSIRO to be more involved in the practical problems of manufacturing . . .

SPEECH.PARA: There are three principal reasons for the decline in the net value of rural production. The first, and probably the most important, is the agricultural policies of Australia's major trading nations. The European Economic Community's protectionist policies and subsidisation of inefficient European agricultural industries have led to a glut of agricultural products on world markets. Much of our present rural industry was built on the premise that we would be the food bowl of the world, particularly of Great Britain, and Europe. The close bonds felt by most Australians to Great Britain led us to Gallipoli, where the cream of our youth bled for the glory of the Empire. In the Second World War our troops were again utilised to the advantage of Great Britain in a conflict of European origin. Our farmers were very active in keeping Great Britain alive during those terrible years.

One would have thought that our sacrifices as a nation would have led to reciprocity and that our loyalty would have guaranteed our farmers a market in Europe, particularly in Great Britain, and that, indeed, loyalty and sacrifice were a two-way deal. Australia knows the history of what its sacrifice and loyalty to Europe and Great Britain in the past have produced. It has been found that our produce is denied access to European markets. Australia and New Zealand were again sacrificed to the glory of the Empire. Some glory, and some Empire! It is not as though our agricultural production is uncompetitive. Our farmers can produce cost effective goods and can compete fairly in any world market. Attempts in the past week to reopen discussions on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade have been blocked by the French. Surely there is a no more singular and isolationist nation than France, a nation where our war dead lie in their thousands, a nation which ignores the world and which, in the Pacific region, still acts in contempt of indigenous inhabitants' rights and wishes. The colonial mentality lives on in Europe and exacts a heavy toll from our farmers.

The first problem I mentioned is the direct course of the second major problem; that is the high levels of accumulated stocks in nearly all major rural commodities. I refer to commodities which are being dumped at well below realistic cost in world markets. The third major problem concerns the increased costs of production. In the face of these difficulties farmers in Australia have demonstrated their capacity for change-not change for change's sake but change in response to economic reasons. Farmers are constantly reappraising their methods in response to economic circumstances. Many changes are quite small but in aggregate they represent the means by which farmers continually increase productivity in the face of adverse trends which have confronted them.

Dalgety Farmers Ltd recently conducted market research which examined, among other things, farmer aspirations, productivity measures, input expenditure intentions, the type of service likely to be in demand in the future, and the availability of funds to meet the various demands of the farming community. Some 1,222 farmers were interviewed in all States except Tasmania. They were involved mainly in the beef, sheep and grain industries. Some of the results are of interest and, indeed, pertinent to this debate. More than 46 per cent of respondents expressed a positive interest in diversification, with grain producers more interested than sheep or beef producers. Fifty-three per cent of respondents under 50 years of age expressed a positive interest, compared with only 35 per cent over 50 years. Around 70 per cent of all beef, sheep, wheat and grain producers estimated that in the future they would be involved in more intensive farming methods.

The availability of diversification and more intensive farming methods is in turn tied to rural research and the dissemination of research information to farmers. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) indicated in his second reading speech, three recent inquiries into the role of the Commonwealth in rural research all recommended substantial changes. It is of interest to listen to those opposite who say that there has been no consultation. They have forgotten those three inquiries and the intensive consultation which was carried on with rural industry in the course of those inquiries. Changes recommended by those inquiries are now being recognised in the Bills before the House, particularly in regard to research conducted through the rural industry research funds. There was evidence to suggest that the funding of rural research has been declining in real terms in recent years, particularly the producers' and the Commonwealth's contributions, in spite of the 1976 recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission that funding be maintained in real terms at the 1976 levels. There also appears to be scope for the more effective use of scarce resources in agricultural research. In a recent review of pasture, crop and animal systems initiated by the Standing Committee on Agriculture, it was concluded that greater integration and co-ordination and co-operation both within and between research organisations was needed. The review stated:

The view of the working party is that currently there is too much fragmented single-objective research . . . There is a need to ensure that expenditure on research activities is rationalised in order to ensure that physical, biological and economic restraints to increasing the efficiency of agricultural production and marketing are approached in a co-ordinated manner.

I believe it is a truism that if substantially more resources are to be devoted to rural research most will have to come from producers through an expanded rural industry research levy system. They are ultimately the beneficiaries of such research. For producers to be convinced that it is in their own interests to expand rural research funding through an expanded levy system they must be convinced, first, that those funds will be used effectively, implying a possible review of the organisation and the setting of priorities for research. Second, they must be convinced that expanded producer contributions will not just be offset by lower direct government contributions. The challenges for Australian agriculture are not short term. There is no panacea for immediately improving the current situation of low farm income levels. To improve the income situation of farmers, there will need to be progress in all areas where policies have a bearing. There is no short term pick-up in sight in the world trading environment but the longer term is more promising. This Government recognises the necessity of a more coherent, integrated national approach to rural research. Agriculture has shown that it can battle and adjust to fluctuating economic fortunes. In that battle it has the support of the Government. The Government is serious about attacking farm costs, improving farm productivity and taking the tension out of the cost-price squeeze. This Bill represents a significant expansion in research expenditure and at the same time rationalises expenditure on research activities. I commend the Bill to the House.

In its report it is stated:
The Group considers there are a number of valid arguments in support of public funding:
These arguments are summed up in four points as follows:
Individual farms are too small to carry out advanced agricultural research since the expenditure threshold for scientists and equipment is beyond the capacity of the individual farm.

The community, by taking a longer term and sometimes different perspective on potential research benefits, is often prepared to fund research activities which would not be considered 'economic' by private firms.
Private firms often cannot capture the gains from research, especially if the new knowledge cannot be incorporated in a patent . . .

The group said:

Overall, the Group believes that agricultural research funding should be increased and that increased expenditure should be concentrated on applied research. The benefits producers derive from research justify an increase in their proportionate contribution to research funding. The Group considers that research is an appropriate area for providing assistance to raise farmer incomes on the grounds discussed . . . in another part of the report.

Economic analyses in a number of countries point to agricultural research being highly profitable and having a significant effect on the rate of productivity increase.

Whilst supporting this Bill, I also support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the National Party. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —A cynic has said that life is extinct on other planets because their scientists were more advanced than ours. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has introduced these seven Bills which are being debated cognately. I wish to talk in particular on the Rural Industries Research Bill 1985. As with many other useful rural industry Bills introduced by this Minister, the Bill aims to rationalise administration and organisation of a government facility, in this case, the rural industries research trust funds. It aims to reduce administrative costs for both industry and government. The present legislation, covering 11 rural industry research funds, will be replaced by one Act. This will reduce the volume of research fund legislation and will mean that new research funds can be added if industries seek them and the Government agrees.

SPEECH.PARA: This single Act will clearly specify the objectives for rural industry research funds and there will be a broader definition of research which can be funded. New selection arrangements will be adopted to make sure that the best available people are nominated for appointment to research fund councils. In order that these rural research funds are made more responsive to their industries, the chairpersons will, in future, formally present the fund's annual report to the executive of the relevant industry body. They will have to account directly for their performance. There will also be an annual co-ordination meeting for all research fund chairpersons so that matters of common interest can be discussed. Government and industry presently each contribute about $32m to industry research. In addition, the Government provides further rural research funds through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, universities and colleges, and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

There have been a series of reviews, papers and discussions in recent years about whether there is enough rural research in Australia. They all agree that research and development are needed if rural industries are to be profitable. They agree that many benefits flow to rural industries and the community from rural research. Successful programs in the past, such as the control of rabbit numbers and of some other rural pests, such as prickly pear, give dramatic and highly visible evidence of the benefits of research. An example of the cost benefits of research to rural industry is research on the control of feral animals. Feral animal populations are increasing dramatically. The introduction of the exotic disease foot and mouth into presently uncontrollable feral animal populations would have disastrous economic consequences for the entire country. In addition to the dangers from these exotic diseases, farmers are suffering heavy stock losses from dog, fox and pig attacks, and the community as a whole is already affected by these losses in rural income and by the loss of many areas of natural flora and fauna as a result of feral pig rootings and the decimation of native wildlife.

A recent search conference which I convened at Snowy Station, Dalgety, has recommended species plans for each feral animal threat. This sort of plan requires a clear statement of the threat and a proposal for action. The conference sought the co-operation and financial involvement not only of the Government, but also of primary industries-industries which have a vested interest in feral animal control. The Bill allows for such a partnership. Berenice Walters of the Australian Native Dog Training Society has estimated, for instance, that the pure dingo will eventually disappear due to cross breeding in the wild with the feral dog. Some farmers are saying that this has already happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —Feral goats are a big problem.
—As the Minister said, feral goats are developing into a real problem.
—Especially in here.

—Not only in this place. Feral goats and wild boars are to be found in this region. They are causing a lot of damage to not only our native flora and fauna but also our livestock. SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, issued in October 1982, points to the obvious gains to be made from rural research and development. This Bill will mean that more dollars will be gained from each dollar spent. It will also mean that those who administer and undertake research will be fully accountable to the provider of funds. The Senate Committee was alarmed to find that, despite the continuing need for rural research, Commonwealth support for research was declining in real terms. The money available to rural industry research funds fell, under the previous Liberal Government, by a staggering $10.1m between 1975 and 1980. I am pleased that the present Government recognises the importance of rural research to rural industry and, accordingly, has increased research funding in the last Budget.

Subject to Budget circumstances, there is scope in this Bill for government contributions to rural research councils to be doubled over the next five years. This means that industries concerned with rural research will be able to seek matched levy increases of up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of the production of their industries. Dairy farmers have told me recently that although they fully recognise the need for reduced production, this does not take away the need for research from which our export and domestic markets can benefit. The Bill does not apply to fisheries at this stage as discussions with the fishing industry on the necessary organisational and administrative arrangements are still under way. Under the Bill research committees will be replaced by research councils and the councils will aim to increase commercial returns to the industries concerned by improving the production, processing, storage, transport or marketing of relevant agricultural commodities.

When agreement is reached with the fishing industry for its inclusion in these new arrangements, major advantages could result from research on preservation of the resource, catch methods, development of new fisheries and marketing techniques. The largest trawl fishery in Australia is located in Eden-Monaro. Suggestions by the Trawler Owners Association to introduce the new viatel system of Telecom Australia to provide increased efficiency and cost savings in the marketing of fresh fish would greatly benefit trawl fishermen who are presently suffering from economic distress.

Les Warren of Eden, a tuna fisherman, is attempting to develop the skipjack fishery as an alternative to the southern bluefin tuna fishery. Peter Bell of the Ulladulla Fishermen's Co-operative is developing the technique of handling and marketing the royal red prawn. All these ventures in Eden-Monaro will gain substantial export income for Australia and research money will have been well spent.

This Government has developed the new arrangements for rural research following calls over many years for improvements in the operation of rural industry research funds. These calls have come from industry organisations such as the National Farmers Federation. I commend the Minister for introducing this Bill and I support it.

The tobacco industry warrants special consideration for research funding for two main reasons:
